{"uri": "8139738515", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "06:08:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T06:08:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T06:07:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/sport/article/2024/may/22/celtics-pacers-report-east-finals-game-one", "title": "Brown's game-tying three lifts Celtics to Game 1 win over Pacers in East finals", "body": "Celtics beats Pacers 133-128 in OT to take 1-0 lead in East finalsBrown hits tying three as Tatum leads way with 36 points\n\nThe Celtics entered the playoffs expecting to get everyone's best shot.\n\nThe East's top seed barely survived a tough one to open the Eastern Conference finals.\n\nJayson Tatum scored 36 points, including 10 in overtime after Jaylen Brown's tying three-pointer with 6.1 seconds remaining in regulation, and Boston rallied just in time for a 133-128 victory over the Indiana Pacers on Tuesday night.\n\nJrue Holiday added a season-high 28 points and Brown finished with 26.\n\n\"Welcome to the NBA playoffs. You've just got to manage your emotions. Anything can happen,\" Brown said of his tying three. \"It's not over until the final buzzer sounds. ... It's not over until it's over. We found a way to win the game at the very end.\"\n\nIt gave his team a new life and helped it hang on to home-court advantage with Game 2 set for Thursday in Boston.\n\nBut guarding against complacency was also on the mind of Tatum. The Celtics have lost Game 2 in each of their previous two series.\n\n\"It doesn't prove anything,\" Tatum said. \"We won a big-time game. The series is far from over.\"\n\nTyrese Haliburton had 25 points and 10 assists for the Pacers, who knocked down 13 three-pointers and scored 56 points in the paint against a Celtics team still playing without seven-footer Kristaps Porzingis.\n\nBut Boston dialed up their defense, finishing with 11 steals - three each by Brown, Tatum and Holiday. The Celtics become the first team in NBA playoff history to have three players record 25 points and three steals in a game.\n\nThe Celtics were cold for most of the game from three-point range, but ended the night 15 of 45 from beyond the arc.\n\n\"We keep talking about protecting home court,\" Celtics forward Al Horford said. \"It's whatever it takes.\"\n\nPascal Siakam added 24 points and 12 rebounds. Myles Turner finished with 23 points and 10 rebounds for the sixth-seeded Pacers, who twice turned it over with a three-point lead in the final 30 seconds of regulation.\n\nBrown made them pay for the second one, hitting a three from the corner with Siakam right in his face to tie it at 117.\n\n\"Jrue made a good pass, (Derrick White) set a great screen and the rest is history,\" Brown said.\n\nCeltics coach Joe Mazzulla like the poise Brown showed.\n\n\"Jaylen had great balance,\" he said. \"Great pass, great shot.\"\n\nPacers coach Rick Carlisle said the loss was \"totally on me\" for not calling a timeout to advance the ball before their turnover that set up Brown's shot.\n\nAsked about the 21 turnovers Indiana committed, Haliburton said many of them were preventable.\n\n\"I think it's more on us,\" he said. \"I just felt like more of them were probably on us than them forcing turnovers.\"\n\nThe Celtics are now 2-2 when their opponent scores 100 or more points.\n\nHoliday said the Celtics never panicked after falling behind late in regulation\n\n\"I think we always knew that there's always a chance. We've seen crazy stuff happen all the time,\" Holiday said. \"I don't think that we think we lost the game until we actually lost the game and that's part of the reason why we were so resilient.\"\n\nIndiana went back ahead 123-121 when Haliburton hit all three free throws after being fouled with 1:46 remaining. Tatum then muscled in a layup and was fouled by TJ McConnell. He completed the three-point play to put Boston ahead for good.\n\nThe Pacers turned it over again, this time by Haliburton. The ball found its way to Tatum at the top of key. He pumped, sidestepped a defender and sunk a three to make it 127-123 with 43 seconds left.\n\nWhite and Siakam traded layups. Holiday was fouled and hit two free throws to give Boston a 131-125 cushion.\n\n\"It's unfortunate we did so many good things in this game that it came down to a couple of mistakes at the end, but it's the NBA playoffs,\" Carlisle said. \"We've got to learn from it and we've got to bounce back.\"", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Guardian"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-05-364666949", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "13:38:30", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T13:38:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T03:01:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.thescore.com/nba/news/2916289", "title": "Celtics force OT on miracle, top Pacers in Game 1", "body": "11h ago\n\nNathaniel S. Butler / National Basketball Association / Getty\n\nBOSTON (AP) -- The Celtics entered the playoffs expecting to get everyone's best shot.\n\nThe East's top seed barely survived a tough one to open the Eastern Conference finals.\n\nJayson Tatum scored 36 points, including 10 in overtime after Jaylen Brown's tying 3-pointer with 6.1 seconds remaining in regulation, and Boston rallied just in time for a 133-128 victory over the Indiana Pacers on Tuesday night.\n\nJrue Holiday added a season-high 28 points and Brown finished with 26.\n\n\"Welcome to the NBA playoffs. You've just got to manage your emotions. Anything can happen,\" Brown said of his tying 3. \"It's not over until the final buzzer sounds. ... It's not over until it's over. We found a way to win the game at the very end.\"\n\nIt gave his team a new life and helped it hang on to home-court advantage with Game 2 set for Thursday in Boston.\n\nBut guarding against complacency was also on the mind of Tatum. The Celtics have lost Game 2 in each of their previous two series.\n\n\"It doesn't prove anything,\" Tatum said. \"We won a big-time game. The series is far from over.\"\n\nTyrese Haliburton had 25 points and 10 assists for the Pacers, who knocked down 13 3-pointers and scored 56 points in the paint against a Celtics team still playing without 7-footer Kristaps Porzingis.\n\nBut Boston dialed up its defense, finishing with 11 steals -- three each by Brown, Tatum and Holiday. The Celtics become the first team in NBA playoff history to have three players record 25 points and three steals in a game.\n\nThe Celtics were cold for most of the game from 3-point range, but ended the night 15 of 45 from beyond the arc.\n\n\"We keep talking about protecting home court,\" Celtics forward Al Horford said. \"It's whatever it takes.\"\n\nPascal Siakam added 24 points and 12 rebounds. Myles Turner finished with 23 points and 10 rebounds for the sixth-seeded Pacers, who twice turned it over with a three-point lead in the final 30 seconds of regulation.\n\nBrown made them pay for the second one, hitting a 3 from the corner with Siakam right in his face to tie it at 117.\n\n\"Jrue made a good pass, (Derrick White) set a great screen and the rest is history,\" Brown said.\n\nCeltics coach Joe Mazzulla like the poise Brown showed.\n\n\"Jaylen had great balance,\" he said. \"Great pass, great shot.\"\n\nPacers coach Rick Carlisle said the loss was \"totally on me\" for not calling a timeout to advance the ball before their turnover that set up Brown's shot.\n\nAsked about the 21 turnovers Indiana committed, Haliburton said many of them were preventable.\n\n\"I think it's more on us,\" he said. \"I just felt like more of them were probably on us than them forcing turnovers.\"\n\nThe Celtics are now 2-2 when their opponent scores 100 or more points.\n\nHoliday said the Celtics never panicked after falling behind late in regulation\n\n\"I think we always knew that there's always a chance. We've seen crazy stuff happen all the time,\" Holiday said. \"I don't think that we think we lost the game until we actually lost the game and that's part of the reason why we were so resilient.\"\n\nIndiana went back ahead 123-121 when Haliburton hit all three free throws after being fouled with 1:46 remaining. Tatum then muscled in a layup and was fouled by T.J. McConnell. He completed the three-point play to put Boston ahead for good.\n\nThe Pacers turned it over again, this time by Haliburton. The ball found its way to Tatum at the top of key. He pumped, sidestepped a defender and sunk a 3 to make it 127-123 with 43 seconds left.\n\nWhite and Siakam traded layups. Holiday was fouled and hit two free throws to give Boston a 131-125 cushion.\n\n\"It's unfortunate we did so many good things in this game that it came down to a couple of mistakes at the end, but it's the NBA playoffs,\" Carlisle said. \"We've got to learn from it and we've got to bounce back.\"", "source": {"uri": "thescore.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "theScore.com"}, "authors": {"uri": "8139655398", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "05:00:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T05:00:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T04:59:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.staradvertiser.com/2024/05/21/sports/sports-breaking/celtics-survive-pacers-in-ot-to-take-game-1-of-east-finals/", "title": "Celtics survive Pacers in OT to take Game 1 of East finals | Honolulu Star-Advertiser", "body": "Indiana Pacers guard T.J. McConnell defends against Boston Celtics forward Jayson Tatum in overtime.\n\nThe Indiana Pacers came into Boston and pushed the Celtics to the brink tonight in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference finals.\n\nIndiana was up by five with just under two minutes left in regulation, but Boston found a way to force overtime before going on to win 133-128 to open the best-of-seven series on a high note.\n\nNow the top-seeded Celtics will try to win Game 2, something they haven't been able to do this postseason. They failed to go up 2-0 on the Miami Heat in the first round, then had to settle for a 1-1 series against the Cleveland Cavaliers in the semifinals.\n\n\"We just gotta be prepared,\" Boston star Jaylen Brown said. \"We know it. We've seen it. We've been hearing it. Now we just have to come out and execute and be better. We will.\"\n\nGame 2 of the Eastern Conference finals is scheduled for Thursday in Boston.\n\nJayson Tatum collected a game-high 36 points and 12 rebounds in Boston's Game 1 victory against Indiana. He scored 10 points in overtime, including five straight that gave the Celtics a 127-123 lead with 42.9 seconds to play.\n\nJrue Holiday added 28 points and Brown finished with 26 for Boston.\n\nAndrew Nembhard canned a 3-pointer to put the Pacers up 115-110 with 1:57 remaining in the fourth quarter, but then the Celtics took over.\n\nHoliday converted a layup and Brown sank two free throws to get Boston within one, 115-114, with 57.4 seconds to go. Nembhard stemmed the tide with a jumper, and Indiana took its 117-114 edge into what was originally supposed to be the game's final seconds.\n\nBut Brown knocked down a trey from the corner, knotting things at 117 with 6.1 seconds on the clock. Indiana star guard Tyrese Haliburton missed a 3-pointer at the buzzer, sending the contest to overtime.\n\nThree free throws from Haliburton in the extra session put the Pacers ahead 123-121 with 1:46 left, but Tatum answered with a three-point play, and the Celtics never gave up the lead the rest of the way.\n\nHaliburton had 25 points and 10 assists. Pascal Siakam finished with 24 points, 12 rebounds and seven assists for the sixth-seeded Pacers, who received 23 points from Myles Turner.\n\n\"Our guys just need to concentrate on fighting the way they fought in (Game 1) from start to finish, and we'll be back Thursday,\" Indiana coach Rick Carlisle said. \"We did a lot of good things that we need to continue to do. We've been a tough-minded and resilient team, really for almost the entire second half of the year. We have to continue with that and come back in here on Thursday night.\"\n\nIndiana made 9 of 10 free throws in the game. Boston was 24-for-30 from the foul line.\n\nThe Pacers committed 22 turnovers that led to 32 Celtics points.\n\nThe Celtics led 34-31 after one quarter, and it was 64-64 at halftime. The Pacers used a 9-0 spurt to pull within four points, 92-88, late in the third quarter, and they trailed 94-93 entering the fourth.\n\n\"They scored a lot of points in transition,\" Brown said. \"We gotta clean that up. We want to get them in a half-court game as much as possible.\n\n\"Defense is where we have to hang our hat. We have to make sure we execute on defense and the majority of it is transition -- getting back in transition. No layups. Gotta run.\"", "source": {"uri": "staradvertiser.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Honolulu Star Advertiser"}, "authors": [{"uri": "field_level_media@staradvertiser.com", "name": "Field Level Media", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indiana_Pacers", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Indiana Pacers"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston_Celtics", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Boston Celtics"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Overtime_(sports)", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Overtime (sports)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Boston"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Boston"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indiana", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Indiana"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Indiana"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jayson_Tatum", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Jayson Tatum"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA_Conference_Finals", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "NBA Conference Finals"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyrese_Haliburton", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Tyrese Haliburton"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Nembhard", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Andrew Nembhard"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA_playoffs", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "NBA playoffs"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T._J._McConnell", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "T. {"uri": "8139634821", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "04:41:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T04:41:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T04:40:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://lethbridgeherald.com/sports/national-sports/2024/05/21/tatum-scores-36-celtics-edge-pacers-133128-in-ot-in-game-1-of-east-finals/", "title": "Tatum scores 36, Celtics edge Pacers 133-128 in OT in Game 1 of East finals", "body": "BOSTON (AP) - The Celtics entered the playoffs expecting to get everyone's best shot.\n\nThe East's top seed barely survived a tough one to open the Eastern Conference finals.\n\nJayson Tatum scored 36 points, including 10 in overtime after Jaylen Brown's tying 3-pointer with 6.1 seconds remaining in regulation, and Boston rallied just in time for a 133-128 victory over the Indiana Pacers on Tuesday night.\n\nJrue Holiday added a season-high 28 points and Brown finished with 26.\n\n\"Welcome to the NBA playoffs. You've just got to manage your emotions. Anything can happen,\"\u009d Brown said of his tying 3. \"It's not over until the final buzzer sounds. \"| It's not over until it's over. We found a way to win the game at the very end.\"\u009d\n\nIt gave his team a new life and helped it hang on to home-court advantage with Game 2 set for Thursday in Boston.\n\nTyrese Haliburton had 25 points and 10 assists for the Pacers, who knocked down 13 3-pointers and scored 56 points in the paint against a Celtics team still playing without 7-footer Kristaps Porzingis.\n\nBut Boston dialed up its defence, finishing with 11 steals - three each by Brown, Tatum and Holiday. The Celtics become the first team in NBA playoff history to have three players record 25 points and three steals in a game.\n\nThe Celtics were cold for most of the game from 3-point range, but ended the night 15 of 45 from beyond the arc.\n\n\"We keep talking about protecting home court,\"\u009d Celtics forward Al Horford said. \"It's whatever it takes.\"\u009d\n\nPascal Siakam added 24 points and 12 rebounds. Myles Turner finished with 23 points and 10 rebounds for the sixth-seeded Pacers, who twice turned it over with a three-point lead in the final 30 seconds of regulation.\n\nBrown made them pay for the second one, hitting a 3 from the corner with Siakam right in his face to tie it at 117.\n\n\"Jrue made a good pass, (Derrick White) set a great screen and the rest is history,\"\u009d Brown said.\n\nCeltics coach Joe Mazzulla like the poise Brown showed.\n\n\"Jaylen had great balance,\" he said. \"Great pass, great shot.\"\u009d\n\nPacers coach Rick Carlisle said the loss was \"totally on me\" for not calling a timeout to advance the ball before their turnover that set up Brown's shot.\n\nAsked about the 21 turnovers Indiana committed, Haliburton said many of them were preventable.\n\n\"I think it's more on us,\"\u009d he said. \"I just felt like more of them were probably on us than them forcing turnovers.\"\u009d\n\nThe Celtics are now 2-2 when their opponent scores 100 or more points.\n\nHoliday said the Celtics never panicked after falling behind late in regulation\n\n\"I think we always knew that there's always a chance. We've seen crazy stuff happen all the time,\"\u009d Holiday said. \"I don't think that we think we lost the game until we actually lost the game and that's part of the reason why we were so resilient.\"\u009d\n\nIndiana went back ahead 123-121 when Haliburton hit all three free throws after being fouled with 1:46 remaining. Tatum then muscled in a layup and was fouled by T.J. McConnell. He completed the three-point play to put Boston ahead for good.\n\nThe Pacers turned it over again, this time by Haliburton. The ball found its way to Tatum at the top of key. He pumped, sidestepped a defender and sunk a 3 to make it 127-123 with 43 seconds left.\n\nWhite and Siakam traded layups. Holiday was fouled and hit two free throws to give Boston a 131-125 cushion.\n\n\"It's unfortunate we did so many good things in this game that it came down to a couple of mistakes at the end, but it's the NBA playoffs,\"\u009d Carlisle said. \"We've got to learn from it and we've got to bounce back.\"\u009d", "source": {"uri": "lethbridgeherald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The {"uri": "8139559700", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "03:26:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T03:26:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T03:25:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/boston/news/jaylen-brown-jayson-tatum-celtics-overtime-win-pacers-game-1-nba-playoffs/", "title": "Celtics hang on, escape with overtime win over Pacers in Game 1 of Eastern Conference Finals", "body": "BOSTON -- The Celtics probably should have lost Game 1 of the Eastern Conference Finals. But Jaylen Brown had other plans.\n\nThe Celtics couldn't buy a basket in the final minutes of regulation and nearly let the Pacers steal Game 1 at TD Garden. But after forcing a turnover on an Indiana inbounds, Brown hit a corner three over Pascal Siakam with 5.9 seconds left in regulation to tie the game at 117-117. Tyrese Haliburton had been hitting ridiculous threes all night, but his game-winning bid didn't fall as the buzzer sounded and an extra five minutes was needed to decide Game 1.\n\nJayson Tatum took over in the final minutes of that extra time, scoring 10 of his game-high 36 points over the final 2:27, and the Celtics escaped with a 133-128 victory. Tatum's driving layup and free-throw that followed gave Boston a 124-123 with 1:12 to go, and then he canned a straight-away three with 42.8 seconds left to put the Celtics on top by four.\n\nBrown bullied the ball away from Siakam on the other end, and Derrick White (15 points, 9 assists) put in a layup to essentially seal the game for Boston despite Indy hitting some clutch free throws in the final seconds.\n\nThe Celtics can exhale after outlasting the Pacers in Game 1. But they will have to be much better in Game 2 on Thursday night. The C's have lost three straight Game 2s going back to last year's Eastern Conference Finals.\n\nJoe Mazzulla will have plenty to say about his team's cold streaks and lack of focus at times. But a playoff win is a playoff win, and Boston now owns a 1-0 lead over the Pacers. That's really all that matters at the end of the day.\n\nThe Celtics had everything going their way to start the game. Mazzulla won a challenge 35 seconds in -- the quickest challenge in NBA postseason history -- and Boston raced out to a 12-0 lead. Brown scored 10 of his 26 points in the opening frame, but the Pacers chipped away and had the Celtics lead down to 34-31 at the end of the quarter thanks to 11 points from Obi Toppin off the bench.\n\nBoston built its lead back up to 10 four minutes into the second quarter, but then Myles Turner caught fire for Indiana. The big man was hitting threes, throwing down dunks, and dishing out assists, scoring 12 points in the frame to go with two dimes and two rebounds. Turner finished with 23 points on the night.\n\nHaliburton also got hot at the end of the half, draining a ridiculous three from the Celtics logo in the closing seconds to tie the game at 64-64.\n\nHaliburton (25 points, 10 assists) came out of the locker room and scored the first five points of the second half to give the Pacers their first lead of the game. But the Celtics responded with a 7-0 run off a Horford three and layups by Tatum and Brown to take the lead right back.\n\nBoston went on a 13-0 run later in the frame sparked by some solid defense and Tatum getting into a groove on offense. He hit his first three of the game midway through the third quarter to put the Celtics on top 83-75, and then got three the hard way when he was fouled on a driving layup, giving the Celtics an 87-75 edge.\n\nBut the Pacers responded again, ripping off a quick 9-0 run with Tatum on the bench. Haliburton hit another absurd three at the buzzer, banking it in over Brown to cut Boston's lead to 94-93 heading into the fourth quarter.\n\nThe Celtics went cold after Jrue Holiday (28 points, 8 assists) tipped in his own miss to give them a 104-101 lead with 7:29 in the game, going over three minutes without any points. Indiana went on a 7-0 run thanks to Siakam, who locked down on the defensive end and turned it into points for the Pacers. He snatched a bad pass by Brown out of the air, and then took a feed from Haliburton for a jam to put Indy on top 108-104 with 4:34 to play.\n\nA White three ended that drought for Boston, but the Pacers continued to pour it on. Aaron Nesmith answered with a hoop-and-the-harm at the other end, and Siakam continued to kill the Celtics with his midrange game.\n\nWhite came up with a huge defensive rebound with the Pacers on top 115-112 with 1:12 left, but a trailing Haliburton blocked his three-point bid. After Brown hit a pair of free throws for Boston, Andrew Nembhard hit a jumper with 42 seconds left to build Indiana's lead back up to three. Tatum missed a three-pointer with 45 seconds left that would have tied the game, and when the Celtics got the ball back with 27.7 seconds on the clock, White missed a bunny and Tatum back-rimmed a fadeaway.\n\nThe game felt over that point and a loss inevitable for the Celtics. But Boston got the ball back one final time when Brown glued himself to Siakam and forced Nembhard's inbound pass to hit off the Indy forward's hands and out of bounds with 8.5 seconds left. That set up Brown's game-tying triple, which he hit with Siakam in front of him.\n\nIt was a big-time shot by a big-time player. Brown gave the Celtics an opportunity, and took full advantage of it himself.\n\nThe Celtics have been criticized for their inability to win close games, as well as their issues at closing out quarters and contests. It looked like they were going to do all three at the end of Game 1, but stole a win back from the Pacers thanks to Brown's big shot.", "source": {"uri": "cbsnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8140086097", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "09:52:38", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T09:52:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T09:51:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.sunstar.com.ph/network/boston-stuns-pacers-in-ot", "title": "Boston stuns Pacers in OT", "body": "BOSTON -- The Celtics entered the playoffs expecting to get everyone's best shot.\n\nThe East's top seed barely survived a tough one to open the Eastern Conference finals.\n\nJayson Tatum scored 36 points, including 10 in overtime after Jaylen Brown's tying 3-pointer with 6.1 seconds remaining in regulation, and Boston rallied just in time for a 133-128 victory over the Indiana Pacers on Tuesday night.\n\nJrue Holiday added a season-high 28 points and Brown finished with 26.\n\n\"Welcome to the NBA playoffs. You've just got to manage your emotions. Anything can happen,\" Brown said of his tying 3. \"It's not over until the final buzzer sounds. ... It's not over until it's over. We found a way to win the game at the very end.\"\n\nIt gave his team a new life and helped it hang on to home-court advantage with Game 2 set for Thursday in Boston.\n\nBut guarding against complacency was also on the mind of Tatum. The Celtics have lost Game 2 in each of their previous two series.\n\n\"It doesn't prove anything,\" Tatum said. \"We won a big-time game. The series is far from over.\"\n\nTyrese Haliburton had 25 points and 10 assists for the Pacers, who knocked down 13 3-pointers and scored 56 points in the paint against a Celtics team still playing without 7-footer Kristaps Porzingis.\n\nBut Boston dialed up its defense, finishing with 11 steals -- three each by Brown, Tatum and Holiday. The Celtics become the first team in NBA playoff history to have three players record 25 points and three steals in a game.\n\nThe Celtics were cold for most of the game from 3-point range, but ended the night 15 of 45 from beyond the arc.\n\n\"We keep talking about protecting home court,\" Celtics forward Al Horford said. \"It's whatever it takes.\"\n\nPascal Siakam added 24 points and 12 rebounds. Myles Turner finished with 23 points and 10 rebounds for the sixth-seeded Pacers, who twice turned it over with a three-point lead in the final 30 seconds of regulation.\n\nBrown made them pay for the second one, hitting a 3 from the corner with Siakam right in his face to tie it at 117.\n\n\"Jrue made a good pass, (Derrick White) set a great screen and the rest is history,\" Brown said.\n\nCeltics coach Joe Mazzulla like the poise Brown showed.\n\n\"Jaylen had great balance,\" he said. \"Great pass, great shot.\"\n\nPacers coach Rick Carlisle said the loss was \"totally on me\" for not calling a timeout to advance the ball before their turnover that set up Brown's shot.\n\nAsked about the 21 turnovers Indiana committed, Haliburton said many of them were preventable.\n\n\"I think it's more on us,\" he said. \"I just felt like more of them were probably on us than them forcing turnovers.\"\n\nThe Celtics are now 2-2 when their opponent scores 100 or more points.\n\nHoliday said the Celtics never panicked after falling behind late in regulation\n\n\"I think we always knew that there's always a chance. We've seen crazy stuff happen all the time,\" Holiday said. \"I don't think that we think we lost the game until we actually lost the game and that's part of the reason why we were so resilient.\" / {"uri": "2024-05-364071822", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "04:20:22", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T04:20:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T03:52:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/sports/national_sports/tatum-scores-36-brown-hits-3-to-force-ot-and-celtics-edge-pacers-133-128/article_5e7fe4be-80e1-522b-b12d-f0beca873b7c.html", "title": "Tatum scores 36, Brown hits 3 to force OT and Celtics edge Pacers 133-128 in Game 1 of East finals", "body": "BOSTON (AP) -- Jayson Tatum scored 36 points, including 10 in overtime after Jaylen Brown's tying 3-pointer with 6.1 seconds remaining in regulation, and the Boston Celtics rallied just in time for a 133-128 victory over the Indiana Pacers on Tuesday night in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference finals.\n\nJrue Holiday added a season-high 28 points and Brown finished with 26.\n\nGame 2 is Thursday night in Boston.\n\nTyrese Haliburton had 25 points and 10 assists for the Pacers, who knocked down 13 3-pointers and scored 56 points in the paint against a Celtics team still playing without 7-footer Kristaps Porzingis.\n\nBut Boston dialed up its defense, finishing with 11 steals -- three each by Brown, Tatum and Holiday. The Celtics become the first team in NBA playoff history to have three players record 25 points and three steals in a game.\n\n\"We keep talking about protecting home court,\" Celtics forward Al Horford said. \"It's whatever it takes.\"\n\nPascal Siakam added 24 points and 12 rebounds. Myles Turner finished with 23 points and 10 rebounds for the sixth-seeded Pacers, who twice turned it over with a three-point lead in the final 30 seconds of regulation.\n\nBrown made them pay for the second one, hitting a 3 from the corner with Siakam right in his face to tie it at 117.\n\n\"Jaylen had great balance,\" Celtics coach Joe Mazzulla said. \"Great pass, great shot.\"\n\nPacers coach Rick Carlisle said the loss was \"totally on me\" for not calling a timeout to advance the ball before their turnover that set up Brown's shot.\n\nAsked about the 21 turnovers Indiana committed, Haliburton said many of them were preventable.\n\n\"I think it's more on us,\" he said. \"I just felt like more of them were probably on us than them forcing turnovers.\"\n\nThe Celtics are now 2-2 when their opponent scores 100 or more points.\n\n\"I think we always knew that there's always a chance. We've seen crazy stuff happen all the time,\" Holiday said. \"I don't think that we think we lost the game until we actually lost the game and that's part of the reason why we were so resilient.\"\n\nIndiana went back ahead 123-121 when Haliburton hit all three free throws after being fouled with 1:46 remaining. Tatum then muscled in a layup and was fouled by T.J. McConnell. He completed the three-point play to put Boston ahead for good.\n\nThe Pacers turned it over again, this time by Haliburton. The ball found its way to Tatum at the top of key. He pumped, sidestepped a defender and sunk a 3 to make it 127-123 with 43 seconds left.\n\nDerrick White and Siakam traded layups. Holiday was fouled and hit two free throws to give Boston a 131-125 cushion.\n\n\"It's unfortunate we did so many good things in this game that it came down to a couple of mistakes at the end, but it's the NBA playoffs,\" Carlisle said. \"We've got to learn from it and we've got to bounce back\"\n\nAP NBA: https://apnews.com/hub/nba", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8139645501", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "04:51:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T04:51:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T04:50:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/sports/national-sports/2024/05/21/tatum-scores-36-celtics-edge-pacers-133128-in-ot-in-game-1-of-east-finals/", "title": "Tatum scores 36, Celtics edge Pacers 133-128 in OT in Game 1 of East finals - Medicine Hat News", "body": "SUBSCRIBE NOW BOSTON (AP) - The Celtics entered the playoffs expecting to get everyone's best shot. The East's top seed barely survived a tough one to open the Eastern Conference finals. Jayson Tatum scored 36 points, including 10 in overtime after Jaylen Brown's tying 3-pointer with 6.1 seconds remaining in regulation, and Boston rallied just in time for a 133-128 victory over the Indiana Pacers on Tuesday night. Jrue Holiday added a season-high 28 points and Brown finished with 26. \"Welcome to the NBA playoffs. You've just got to manage your emotions. Anything can happen,\"\u009d Brown said of his tying 3. \"It's not over until the final buzzer sounds. \"| It's not over until it's over. We found a way to win the game at the very end.\"\u009d It gave his team a new life and helped it hang on to home-court advantage with Game 2 set for Thursday in Boston. Tyrese Haliburton had 25 points and 10 assists for the Pacers, who knocked down 13 3-pointers and scored 56 points in the paint against a Celtics team still playing without 7-footer Kristaps Porzingis. But Boston dialed up its defence, finishing with 11 steals - three each by Brown, Tatum and Holiday. The Celtics become the first team in NBA playoff history to have three players record 25 points and three steals in a game. The Celtics were cold for most of the game from 3-point range, but ended the night 15 of 45 from beyond the arc. \"We keep talking about protecting home court,\"\u009d Celtics forward Al Horford said. \"It's whatever it takes.\"\u009d Pascal Siakam added 24 points and 12 rebounds. Myles Turner finished with 23 points and 10 rebounds for the sixth-seeded Pacers, who twice turned it over with a three-point lead in the final 30 seconds of regulation. Brown made them pay for the second one, hitting a 3 from the corner with Siakam right in his face to tie it at 117. \"Jrue made a good pass, (Derrick White) set a great screen and the rest is history,\"\u009d Brown said. Celtics coach Joe Mazzulla like the poise Brown showed. \"Jaylen had great balance,\" he said. \"Great pass, great shot.\"\u009d Pacers coach Rick Carlisle said the loss was \"totally on me\" for not calling a timeout to advance the ball before their turnover that set up Brown's shot. Asked about the 21 turnovers Indiana committed, Haliburton said many of them were preventable. \"I think it's more on us,\"\u009d he said. \"I just felt like more of them were probably on us than them forcing turnovers.\"\u009d The Celtics are now 2-2 when their opponent scores 100 or more points. Holiday said the Celtics never panicked after falling behind late in regulation \"I think we always knew that there's always a chance. We've seen crazy stuff happen all the time,\"\u009d Holiday said. \"I don't think that we think we lost the game until we actually lost the game and that's part of the reason why we were so resilient.\"\u009d Indiana went back ahead 123-121 when Haliburton hit all three free throws after being fouled with 1:46 remaining. Tatum then muscled in a layup and was fouled by T.J. McConnell. He completed the three-point play to put Boston ahead for good. The Pacers turned it over again, this time by Haliburton. The ball found its way to Tatum at the top of key. He pumped, sidestepped a defender and sunk a 3 to make it 127-123 with 43 seconds left. White and Siakam traded layups. Holiday was fouled and hit two free throws to give Boston a 131-125 cushion. \"It's unfortunate we did so many good things in this game that it came down to a couple of mistakes at the end, but it's the NBA playoffs,\"\u009d Carlisle said. \"We've got to learn from it and we've got to bounce back.\"\u009d -- AP NBA:", "source": {"uri": "medicinehatnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Medicine Hat News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "canadian_press@medicinehatnews.com", "name": "Canadian Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA_playoffs", {"uri": "8139637007", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "04:43:27", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T04:43:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T04:42:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/sports/celtics-survive-in-regulation-take-game-1-from-pacers-in-overtime-5654767", "title": "Celtics Survive in Regulation, Take Game 1 From Pacers in Overtime", "body": "BOSTON -- Jayson Tatum scored 36 points, including 10 in overtime after Jaylen Brown's tying 3-pointer with 6.1 seconds remaining in regulation, and the Boston Celtics rallied just in time for a 133-128 victory over the Indiana Pacers in Tuesday night's opening game of the NBA's Eastern Conference finals.\n\nJrue Holiday added a season-high 28 points, and Brown finished with 26.\n\nGame 2 of the series is set for Thursday night in Boston.\n\nTyrese Haliburton had 25 points and 10 assists for the Pacers, who knocked down 13 shots from 3-point range and scored 56 points in the paint against a Celtics team still playing without injured 7-footer Kristaps Porzingis.\n\nBut Boston dialed up its defense, finishing with 11 steals, including three each by Brown, Tatum, and Holiday. The Celtics become the first team in NBA playoff history to have three players record 25 points and three steals in a game.\n\n\"We keep talking about protecting home court,\" Celtics forward Al Horford said. \"It's whatever it takes.\"\n\nPascal Siakam added 24 points and 12 rebounds for Indiana. Myles Turner finished with 23 points and 10 rebounds for the sixth-seeded Pacers, who twice turned the ball over while holding a three-point lead in the final 30 seconds of regulation.\n\nBrown made Indiana pay the second time, hitting a 3 from the corner with Siakam right in his face to tie it at 117.\n\n\"Jaylen had great balance,\" Celtics Coach Joe Mazzulla said. \"Great pass, great shot.\"\n\nPacers Coach Rick Carlisle said the loss was \"totally on me\" for not calling a timeout to advance the ball before their turnover that set up Brown's shot.\n\nAsked about the 21 turnovers Indiana committed, Haliburton said many of them were preventable.\n\n\"I think it's more on us,\" he said. \"I just felt like more of them were probably on us than them forcing turnovers.\"\n\nThe Celtics are now 2-2 when their opponent scores 100 or more points.\n\n\"I think we always knew that there's always a chance. We've seen crazy stuff happen all the time,\" Holiday said. \"I don't think that we think we lost the game until we actually lost the game, and that's part of the reason why we were so resilient.\"\n\nIndiana went back ahead 123-121 when Haliburton hit all three free throws after being fouled with 1:46 remaining. Tatum then muscled in a layup and was fouled by T.J. McConnell. He completed the three-point play to put Boston ahead for good.\n\nThe Pacers turned it over again, this time by Haliburton. The ball found its way to Tatum at the top of the key. He pumped, sidestepped a defender, and buried a 3 to make it 127-123 with 43 seconds left.\n\nDerrick White and Siakam traded layups. Holiday was fouled and hit two free throws to give Boston a 131-125 cushion.\n\n\"It's unfortunate we did so many good things in this game that it came down to a couple of mistakes at the end, but You've just got to manage your emotions. Anything can happen,\" Brown said of his tying 3. \"It's not over until the final buzzer sounds. ... It's not over until it's over. We found a way to win the game at the very end.\"\n\nIt gave his team a new life and helped it hang on to home-court advantage with Game 2 set for Thursday in Boston.\n\nTyrese Haliburton had 25 points and 10 assists for the Pacers, who knocked down 13 3-pointers and scored 56 points in the paint against a Celtics team still playing without 7-footer Kristaps Porzingis.\n\nBut Boston dialed up its defense, finishing with 11 steals -- three each by Brown, Tatum and Holiday. {"uri": "8139720930", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "05:55:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T05:55:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T05:54:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/jayson-tatum-perfect-nsfw-reaction-chaos-celtics-game-1-win/", "title": "Jayson Tatum Had Perfect NSFW Reaction to 'Chaos' in Celtics' Game 1 Win", "body": "The Boston Celtics survived a wild fourth quarter and overtime to take Game 1 over the Indiana Pacers.\n\nHighlights Game 1 of the Eastern Conference Finals saw a wild finish between the Celtics and the Pacers. The Celtics managed to survive the chaos of the fourth quarter and overtime, thanks to heroics from Jaylen Brown and Jayson Tatum. The Celtics' battle-tested experience proved to be their advantage over the Pacers in Game 1.\n\nThe 2024 NBA Playoffs have been a doozy, to say the least, and Game 1 of the Eastern Conference Finals between the Boston Celtics and the Indiana Pacers lived up to the billing. In the end, the No. 1 seeded Celtics managed to survive a resilient effort from the Pacers with a 133-128 overtime win.\n\nIndiana looked well on its way to stealing Game 1. However, the inexperienced Pacers committed some costly miscues down the stretch and the battle-tested Celtics took advantage.\n\nFollowing the game, Jayson Tatum gave a candid NSFW response about his thoughts on the crazy fourth quarter finish that saw Boston showcase its resiliency.\n\n\"That s--- was chaos. That s--- was wild. But... to stay present, stay in the moment. As long as there's time still on the clock and the game is within reach, we feel like we have a chance. This core group has had so many big-time games and big-time moments... I've had a lot of crazy endings in this building.\" - Jayson Tatum\n\nCeltics Survive Game 1 With Wild Sequence Boston's experience came through\n\nThe Pacers had the Celtics on the ropes. With a three-point lead, they had possession of the ball multiple times down the stretch and just needed to play the foul game to complete the series-opening shocker.\n\nHowever, Indiana's inexperience showed, and the team committed multiple miscues within the final 30 seconds of regulation. With a chance to pad onto their lead, Tyrese Haliburton lost the ball while running down the floor, which gave possession back to the Celtics with 27 seconds remaining.\n\nBoston failed to score after Derrick White and Jayson Tatum missed their respective shot attempts. This gave the Pacers the golden opportunity to close out the game. However, Indiana turned the ball over again in the backcourt with 10 seconds left, leaving the door open for the Celtics.\n\nAnd the battle-tested Celtics took advantage. Jaylen Brown came through with the biggest shot of the evening, tying the game with a cold-blooded corner three-pointer that sent the game into overtime.\n\nTatum Takeover In Overtime The Celtics star scored 10 of Boston's 16 points in OT\n\nIf there's one thing to avoid in the NBA playoffs, it's giving a great team like Boston some life. That's, unfortunately, what the Pacers did when they failed to close out the Celtics in regulation. Indiana already had Boston dead in the water. But poor execution down the stretch in the fourth quarter, which Pacers head coach Rick Carlisle took responsibility for, cost them the game.\n\nCeltics Stars in Game 1 vs. Pacers\n\nCategory\n\nJayson Tatum\n\nJaylen Brown\n\nJrue Holiday\n\nPTS\n\n36\n\n26\n\n28\n\nREB\n\n12\n\n7\n\n7\n\nAST\n\n4\n\n5\n\n8\n\nFG-A\n\n12-26\n\n10-20\n\n10-16\n\nWith that, not only did the Celtics take advantage, it also gave Jayson Tatum the opportunity to redeem himself. Tatum had an abysmal fourth quarter. He went just 2-of-7 from the field and missed a wide-open three-pointer during a crucial junction that would have tied the game.\n\nFortunately, Brown was able to save the day for the Celtics, and this opened the door for his fellow All-Star to \"wake up\" and show just what he's made of in the extra period.\n\nTatum scored 10 of Boston's 16 overtime points. He converted on an and-one to give Boston a lead that they did not relinquish and later made the put-away punch, a side-step three-pointer that gave the Celtics a four-point lead with over 40 seconds to go in OT.\n\nAs Tatum said in his post-game comments, Boston has been here before. And in Game 1, their experience and composure proved to be their advantage down the stretch against the up-start Pacers.\n\nRelated Tyrese Haliburton Says Pacers Were Great for 47 Minutes After Brutal {"uri": "2024-05-364076362", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "04:26:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T04:26:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T04:13:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.islandpacket.com/sports/article288624818.html", "title": "Celtics survive Pacers in OT to take Game 1 of East finals", "body": "The Indiana Pacers came into Boston and pushed the Celtics to the brink on Tuesday night in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference finals.\n\nIndiana was up by five with just under two minutes left in regulation, but Boston found a way to force overtime before going on to win 133-128 to open the best-of-seven series on a high note.\n\nNow the top-seeded Celtics will try to win Game 2, something they haven't been able to do this postseason. They failed to go up 2-0 on the Miami Heat in the first round, then had to settle for a 1-1 series against the Cleveland Cavaliers in the semifinals.\n\n\"We just gotta be prepared,\" Boston star Jaylen Brown said. \"We know it. We've seen it. We've been hearing it. Now we just have to come out and execute and be better. We will.\"\n\nGame 2 of the Eastern Conference finals is scheduled for Thursday in Boston.\n\nJayson Tatum collected a game-high 36 points and 12 rebounds in Boston's Game 1 victory against Indiana. He scored 10 points in overtime, including five straight that gave the Celtics a 127-123 lead with 42.9 seconds to play.\n\nJrue Holiday added 28 points and Brown finished with 26 for Boston.\n\nAndrew Nembhard canned a 3-pointer to put the Pacers up 115-110 with 1:57 remaining in the fourth quarter, but then the Celtics took over.\n\nHoliday converted a layup and Brown sank two free throws to get Boston within one, 115-114, with 57.4 seconds to go. Nembhard stemmed the tide with a jumper, and Indiana took its 117-114 edge into what was originally supposed to be the game's final seconds.\n\nBut Brown knocked down a trey from the corner, knotting things at 117 with 6.1 seconds on the clock. Indiana star guard Tyrese Haliburton missed a 3-pointer at the buzzer, sending the contest to overtime.\n\nThree free throws from Haliburton in the extra session put the Pacers ahead 123-121 with 1:46 left, but Tatum answered with a three-point play, and the Celtics never gave up the lead the rest of the way.\n\nHaliburton had 25 points and 10 assists. Pascal Siakam finished with 24 points, 12 rebounds and seven assists for the sixth-seeded Pacers, who received 23 points from Myles Turner.\n\n\"Our guys just need to concentrate on fighting the way they fought in (Game 1) from start to finish, and we'll be back Thursday,\" Indiana coach Rick Carlisle said. \"We did a lot of good things that we need to continue to do. We've been a tough-minded and resilient team, really for almost the entire second half of the year. We have to continue with that and come back in here on Thursday night.\"\n\nIndiana made 9 of 10 free throws in the game. Boston was 24-for-30 from the foul line.\n\nThe Pacers committed 22 turnovers that led to 32 Celtics points.\n\nThe Celtics led 34-31 after one quarter, and it was 64-64 at halftime. The Pacers used a 9-0 spurt to pull within four points, 92-88, late in the third quarter, and they trailed 94-93 entering the fourth.\n\n\"They scored a lot of points in transition,\" Brown said. \"We gotta clean that up. {"uri": "8140087307", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "09:52:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T09:52:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T09:52:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://scoutmediaph.rappler.com/celtics-win-against-pacers-in-eastern-finals/", "title": "Celtics win with overtime victory against Pacers in conference finals, 133-128", "body": "BALAYAN, Batangas -- The Boston Celtics secured their first series win, 1-0, in the Eastern Conference finals after going up against the Indiana Pacers, 133-128, at TD Garden in Boston, Massachusetts, on May 22 (PHT).\n\nJayson Tatum led the game for the Celtics after finishing with 36 points, 12 rebounds, and four assists. He scored 10 of them during overtime after Jaylen Brown's tying 3-pointer with 6.1 seconds left in the game. Boston made a timely comeback that resulted in a victory over the Pacers.\n\nAlong with Tatum, Jrue Holiday added a season-high 28 points, seven rebounds, and 8 assists, and Brown finished with 26 points, 7 rebounds, and five assists.\n\nThe Celtics became the first team in the history of NBA Playoffs that there were three players totaling 25+ points and three steals in a game. This is the ninth time that this has happened in a Conference Finals game ever.\n\nAlthough the Celtics struggled for most of the game with shooting in the 3-point range, they still ended the match with 15 of 45 being knocked down from beyond the arc.\n\n\"Welcome to the NBA playoffs. You've just got to manage your emotions. Anything can happen. It's not over until the final buzzer sounds. It's not over until it's over. We found a way to win the game at the very end,\" Jaylen Brown said.\n\nFor the Pacers, Tyrese Haliburton led the team with 25 points and 10 assists. Pascal Siakam also finished with 24 points, 12 rebounds, and 7 assists. Lastly, Myles Turner with 23 points and 10 rebounds.\n\nHaliburton shot 13 of his 3-pointers and scored 56 points in the paint against the Celtics.\n\nBut Boston leveled up their defense. They finished with 11 steals, three of which were done by Brown, Tatum, and Holiday.\n\nThe Pacers took the lead at 123-121 after Haliburton made all three free throws after being fouled with 1:46 left. T.J. McConnell fouled Tatum after powering through for a layup. He completed the three-point play to secure the Celtics lead for the rest of the game.\n\nThe Pacers had a turnover again, this time by Haliburton. The ball ended up in Tatum's hand at the top of the key. He pumped, sidestepped a defender, and nailed a 3-pointer that made the score 127-123 with 43 seconds remaining.\n\nWhite and Siakam exchanged layups. After Holiday was fouled, he made two free throws which gave the Celtics a lead, 131-125.\n\n\"It's unfortunate we did so many good things in this game that it came down to a couple of mistakes at the end, but it's the NBA playoffs. We've got to learn from it, and we've got to bounce back,\" Pacers' coach Rick Carlisle said.\n\nThe Celtics and Pacers will face each other again at TD Garden in Boston, Massachusetts on May 23, 8 AM {"uri": "8139550182", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "03:16:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T03:16:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T03:15:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://celticswire.usatoday.com/lists/celtics-squeak-past-pacers-133-128-in-game-1-overtime-thriller/", "title": "Celtics squeak past Pacers 133-128 in Game 1 overtime thriller", "body": "The Boston Celtics defeated the Indiana Pacers 133-128 in overtime in a tightly contested game to open game of the 2024 Eastern Conference finals. Game 2 is set for Thursday night in Boston.\n\nDefense was in short supply for much of the game, and Indiana thrived playing fast and aggressive. Boston couldn't quite contain the Pacers, even as the Celtics own scoring attack looked polished and methodical. The resulting foot race kept things close from wire to wire. It took Jaylen Brown connecting on an improbable corner 3-pointer to force overtime. Boston's defense in that overtime period proved to be the key, with Jayson Tatum providing his own heroic 3-pointer to secure a tight Celtics win. Tatum and Brown combined for 62 points, 19 rebounds, and 9 assists in the win.\n\nLet's take a closer look Boston's 133-128 thrilling overtime victory and recap the action from Game 1 of the Eastern Conference finals.\n\nFirst Quarter\n\nThe Celtics owned the NBA's best offensive rating this year, while Indiana has been an average defensive team. After Boston jumped out to a quick 12-0 lead to open the game, it appeared as if the Pacers were overmatched.\n\nIndiana owns the NBA's second-best offensive rating, however, and they soon went on a run of their own. The Pacers defense never really found its footing in the quarter, but thanks to a bevy of shooting, the road team nearly closed the gap by the end of the frame.\n\nBoston's defense looked ok, but Indiana's speed took advantage of any sluggishness on the part of the Celtics. Boston led 34-31 by the close of the quarter.\n\nSecond quarter\n\nThe second quarter looked much like the first. Boston moonwalked on offense, and looked steady and composed. Once again, the Celtics weren't bad on the defensive end, but Indiana eeked out every advantage they could.\n\nThe Pacers looked better on the glass. They had more assists. They worked hard to keep up with Boston, and were rewarded for their effort.\n\nIndiana was particularly efficient from deep. They shot a tidy 8-for-15 on 3-pointers in the first half. Not only did this prevent the Celtics from pulling away, but a deep 3 from Haliburton actually tied the game at 64-64 right before halftime.\n\nThird quarter\n\nMay 21, 2024; Boston, Massachusetts, USA; Indiana Pacers guard Tyrese Haliburton (0) shoots the ball over Boston Celtics guard Jrue Holiday (4) in the first half for game one of the eastern conference finals for the 2024 NBA playoffs at TD Garden. Mandatory Credit: David Butler II-USA TODAY Sports\n\nBoston remained hot on the offensive end. Even before the middle of the third quarter, all five Celtics starters were in double-figures scoring the ball. Part of this success had to do with Boston's patience in getting to the free throw line.\n\nFor the game, the Celtics shot 24-for-30 from the foul line, compared to a 9-for-10 showing from the Pacers. Boston's ability to slow the action down by getting more physical at the rim was a massive pivot for the game.\n\nIndiana's high-octane offense got bogged down a bit as a result, although it recovered a bit as the period came to a close. Another improbable 3-pointer from Haliburton put the score at 94-93 with the final quarter on deck.\n\nFourth quarter\n\nThe Celtics were at their best all game long with Tatum on the floor. His unique combination of size, speed, and playmaking was too much for Indiana to handle, and many of Indiana's best stretches during the game came while the former Duke Blue Devil rested. Tatum had 36 points, 12 rebounds, 4 assists, and 3 steals here in Game 1.\n\nThe Pacers refused to quit, however. Pascal Siakam and Myles Turner both benefitted from Boston's drop defense, gobbling up a number of open looks in the mid-range. This fueled Indiana to a late lead.\n\nJaylen Brown helped save the game for the Celtics. He forced a turnover on the Pacers side of the action with Boston down 3 points before banking in a heroic shot on the opposite end. Free basketball for the crowd at TD Garden.\n\nOvertime\n\nIn overtime Boston found their defensive footing once again. The Celtics forced a number of critical turnovers in this extra period. In total, the Pacers had 21 giveaways for the game, a testament to how effective Boston's defensive was when it was dialed in.\n\nCredit Brown for forcing overtime. And credit Tatum for giving Boston offensive lift at a crucial moment. In the end, though, it was defense that won the day for the Celtics and delivered a big Game 1 victory.\n\nListen to the \"Celtics Lab\" podcast on:\n\nApple Podcasts: https://apple.co/3zBKQY6\n\nSpotify: https://spoti.fi/3GfUPFi\n\nYouTube: https://bit.ly/3F9DvjQ\n\nWhat will the Boston Celtics' looming Eastern Conference finals series with the Indiana Pacers look like? {"uri": "8139636637", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "04:42:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T04:42:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T04:41:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.rappler.com/sports/nba/eastern-conference-finals-game-results-boston-celtics-indiana-pacers-may-21-2024/", "title": "East thriller: Celtics survive Pacers in OT to take conference finals opener", "body": "Stretched to the limit right in the opener, the Celtics find a way to escape the gutsy Pacers in overtime and claim the early upper hand in the Eastern conference finals\n\nThe Indiana Pacers came into Boston and pushed the Celtics to the brink in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference finals on Tuesday night, May 21 (Friday, May 22, Manila time).\n\nIndiana was up by five with just under two minutes left in regulation, but Boston found a way to force overtime before going on to win 133-128 to open the best-of-seven series on a high note.\n\nNow, the top-seeded Celtics will try to win Game 2, something they haven't been able to do this postseason.\n\nThey failed to go up 2-0 on the Miami Heat in the first round, then had to settle for a 1-1 series against the Cleveland Cavaliers in the semifinals.\n\n\"We just gotta be prepared,\" said Boston star Jaylen Brown, who drained a corner three-pointer that made it 117-117 with 6.1 to play in regulation.\n\n\"We know it. We've seen it. We've been hearing it. Now we just have to come out and execute and be better. We will.\"\n\nGame 2 of the Eastern Conference finals is scheduled for Thursday, May 23, in Boston.\n\nJayson Tatum collected a game-high 36 points and 12 rebounds in Boston's Game 1 victory against Indiana. He scored 10 points in overtime, including five straight that gave the Celtics a 127-123 lead with 42.9 seconds to play.\n\nJrue Holiday added 28 points and Brown finished with 26 for Boston.\n\nAndrew Nembhard canned a three-pointer to put the Pacers up 115-110 with 1:57 remaining in the fourth quarter, but then the Celtics took over.\n\nHoliday converted a layup and Brown sank two free throws to get Boston within one, 115-114, with 57.4 seconds to go.\n\nNembhard stemmed the tide with a jumper, and Indiana took its 117-114 edge into what was originally supposed to be the game's final seconds.\n\nBut Brown knocked down a trey from the corner, knotting things at 117 with 6.1 seconds on the clock.\n\nIndiana star guard Tyrese Haliburton missed a three-pointer at the buzzer, sending the contest to overtime.\n\nThree free throws from Haliburton in the extra session put the Pacers ahead 123-121 with 1:46 left, but Tatum answered with a three-point play, and the Celtics never gave up the lead the rest of the way.\n\nHaliburton had 25 points and 10 assists. Pascal Siakam finished with 24 points, 12 rebounds, and 7 assists for the sixth-seeded Pacers, who received 23 points from Myles Turner.\n\n\"Our guys just need to concentrate on fighting the way they fought in (Game 1) from start to finish, and we'll be back Thursday,\" Indiana coach Rick Carlisle said.\n\n\"We did a lot of good things that we need to continue to do. We've been a tough-minded and resilient team, really for almost the entire second half of the year. We have to continue with that and come back in here on Thursday night.\"\n\nIndiana made 9-of-10 free throws in the game. Boston was 24-for-30 from the foul line.\n\nThe Pacers committed 22 turnovers that led to 32 Celtics points.\n\nThe Celtics led 34-31 after one quarter, and it was 64-64 at halftime. The Pacers used a 9-0 spurt to pull within four points, 92-88, late in the third quarter, and they trailed 94-93 entering the fourth.\n\n\"They scored a lot of points in transition,\" Brown said. \"We gotta clean that up. We want to get them in a half-court game as much as possible.\n\n\"Defense is where we have to hang our hat. We have to make sure we execute on defense and the majority of it is transition - getting back in transition. No layups. {"uri": "2024-05-364708475", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "14:11:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T14:11:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T14:03:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/3-celtics-takeaways-insane-game-1-overtime-win-over-pacers", "title": "3 Celtics takeaways from insane Game 1 overtime win over Pacers", "body": "The Celtics mounted a crazy comeback to steal Game 1 from the Pacers on Tuesday night.\n\nBOSTON, MA -- The Boston Celtics had done their best to avoid a last-second thriller in the 2024 NBA Playoffs, but that wasn't going to last forever. Instead of taking care of business early on against the Indiana Pacers, the C's clutched up and prevailed 133-128 in overtime to take a 1-0 series lead in the Eastern Conference Finals.\n\nBoston led by as much as 13 points late in the third quarter, yet Indiana roared back to make it a one-point contest heading into the final frame. The Pacers used that momentum to hit shot after shot and held a 117-114 advantage with 46.1 seconds left in regulation.\n\nThe Green Team never waved the white flag, though. Boston forced some timely turnovers and star Jaylen Brown nailed a corner triple to tie it up with six seconds remaining.\n\nFrom there, the Celtics outscored the Pacers 16-11 in overtime.\n\nThis series opener probably should've belonged to the Pacers, however, the Celtics overcame the most adversity they've faced all postseason to steal the win. So, let's examine three takeaways from Boston's tight victory over Indiana in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference Finals.\n\nThe Celtics showed their resiliency\n\nPrior to their semifinal showdown with the Pacers, the Celtics only had one postseason game decided by single digits. Outside of their 109-102 win in Game 4 over the Cleveland Cavaliers, all of Boston's contests hadn't been particularly close.\n\nThis lack of a truly close victory, fair or not, was held against the Celtics. Some pundits wondered whether or not they could take over in the clutch if they'd never been \"battle-tested\" in the 2024 playoffs.\n\nIn Game 1 versus the Pacers, Boston proved its grit in a stunning comeback that was the definition of a late-game battle.\n\nWith only 10 ticks left in regulation, Indiana had a 97.4% chance of taking a 1-0 series lead, according to ESPN's analytics. Rather than giving up, Brown prevented the Pacers from properly inbounding the ball and then drained the game-tying triple:\n\n\"One, it was just a momentum play that we was able to turn them over and get an extra possession, and that led to a great drive, Jrue made a great pass, [Derrick] White set a good screen, and the rest was history,\" Brown described when asked about his big shot during his postgame presser.\n\nThe Celtics had blown multiple double-digit leads in regulation, yet they didn't let that shake their confidence when it mattered most.\n\n\"Welcome to the NBA playoffs. You just got to manage your emotions, in the game anything can happen,\" Brown stated. \"The game is not over until the final whistle -- the final buzzer sounds. That was a good example of that. We were able to turn it over a little bit towards the end. We had [Tyrese] Haliburton on the sideline, and I was able to get the deflection off of [Pascal] Siakam, that just extended the game. It's not over until it's over. We just found a way to win the game at the very end.\"\n\nAlthough Boston had all the momentum following Indiana's last-second collapse, there was still work to be done. During the regular season, the Celtics had a rough 2-4 record in overtime games, shooting 38% from the field during those extra periods.\n\nOn Tuesday evening, the C's shot 40% from the field in overtime while holding Indiana to just 25% from the floor. Celtics star Jayson Tatum had 10 of Boston's 16 points in the final five minutes, which nearly surpassed the Pacers' overtime point total of 11 points.\n\n\"It really just felt like we had a second chance,\" Tatum said of overtime in his postgame remarks. \"JB gave us a second chance by hitting that shot. And we just talked about it in the huddle. 'We got a second chance. Let's take advantage of it. Let's not mess around. And let's figure out a way to win this game.'\"\n\nFor all the doubts about Boston's preparedness for a hard-fought competition, the Celtics found a way to win in their toughest playoff game yet.\n\nThe Celtics stars aren't afraid to do the dirty work on defense\n\nIn the modern NBA, defense isn't that glamorous. The players who dazzle on offense typically get the most love from the media and fans. As a result, some stars don't emphasize the importance of that aspect of the game.\n\nThankfully for the Celtics, their stars don't typically follow this train of thought. In fact, Tatum and Brown made some of the biggest defensive plays of the night to help clinch the win.\n\nBrown forced a pivotal turnover from Siakam and had three steals overall. Tatum also had three steals and made Pacers star Tyrese Haliburton attempt a wild 3-pointer at the end of regulation. The six combined steals from Boston's dynamic duo nearly equaled the eight steals Indiana had altogether.\n\nHaving two-way stars that are on a mission on both offense and defense is a massive boon for the Celtics. Without that, and award-winning defense from guards Derrick White and Jrue Holiday, Boston wouldn't have even made it to overtime in Game 1.\n\nHowever, Indiana still managed to shoot 53.5% from the field despite the loss. Brown and company know they have work to do on that side of the ball ahead of Game 2:\n\n\"I think just trying to be as consistent as possible on the boards, trying to stop them from transition. They pass the ball up so well, they move the ball so well, especially off the rebound, that sometimes it gets tough,\" he said when asked how the Celtics can slow the Pacers' efficient offense down. \"But something we'll probably go back and take a look at is transition defense.\"\n\nThe Celtics will need more from their bench to counter the Pacers' depth\n\nBoston was fortunate to escape with a 1-0 series lead, and they know they'll need to improve to triumph in this series.\n\nThe bench is particularly aware of that, because without the scoring of center Kristaps Porzingis for the time being, someone else has to step up for the Celtics.\n\nSo far, point guard Payton Pritchard has done his best to contribute off the bench. He notched eight points and two assists in Game 1 and performed well enough to get four minutes in the fourth quarter.\n\nBesides him, Boston's bench was underwhelming in comparison to Indiana's. Pritchard, forward Sam Hauser, and center Luke Kornet combined for 13 points off the pine, while the Pacers' bench had 30 points altogether.\n\nHauser especially struggled, as he bricked his two attempts from deep and had to be subbed out before the end of the first half due to his poor defense. Boston will need more from its reserves if it wants to counter the Pacers, who arguably have the deepest rotation of the remaining playoff teams.\n\nScoring aside, Boston can't afford to have anyone off its bench be a defensive liability. Indiana already has a talented offense, so the Celtics must have all their guys defend at a high level to prevent mismatches from dooming them.", "source": {"uri": "clutchpoints.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8139673549", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "05:14:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T05:14:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T05:14:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/boston/news/brown-tatum-holiday-celtics-good-bad-game-1-pacers-nba-playoffs/", "title": "What went right and what went wrong for the Celtics in their Game 1 win over Pacers", "body": "BOSTON -- You didn't expect the Eastern Conference Finals to be a cakewalk for the Boston Celtics, did you? Despite being massive favorites to win the series, the Celtics nearly let the Pacers steal Game 1 at TD Garden on Tuesday night.\n\nUntil Jaylen Brown stole it right back, sinking a game-tying corner three with 5.9 seconds left in regulation. Then Jayson Tatum took over in overtime, while Jrue Holiday continued to have his best game in a Celtics uniform.\n\nWho says these Celtics aren't battle tested?\n\nIt was frustrating that it even came to that, but we've come to expect that from the Celtics. They went ice cold for a three-minute stretch in the fourth quarter and seemed destined start the Conference Finals with a massive disappointment for a second straight postseason.\n\nThe Celtics didn't play in many close games during the regular season and only one of their previous 10 playoff games was decided by single digits, so questions about their championship mettle have been prevalent since the end of their second-round win over the Cavaliers. The Celtics nearly gave those doubters a lot of fresh ammo on Tuesday night.\n\nInstead, they won a game they really should have loss. It took a lot of guts at the end, a lot of big plays, and a whole lot of luck.\n\nThey're lucky that the Pacers didn't call a timeout to advance the ball before Brown forced a turnover. They're lucky the Pacers didn't foul Brown (who has struggled at the line this postseason) before he put up his game-tying three. They're lucky the Pacers coughed up their chance to put them on the ropes in this series.\n\nBut in the playoffs, it's better to be lucky than to be losers. Now the Celtics have a signature moment of this postseason, and a chance to go up 2-0 on Thursday night.\n\nTatum and Brown (mostly) played like stars\n\nBoth had their frustrating moments, whether it was an untimely turnover or forced shots. They were both pretty cold from downtown, with Tatum going 2-for-8 and Brown just 1-for-4 from deep.\n\nBut they were stars when the Celtics needed them to be stars. All Indiana had to do was inbound the ball to win at the end of regulation, but Brown velcro'd himself to Pascal Siakam and forced a Pacers turnover, setting up his game-saving three and the biggest made bucket of his career. He had another big defensive play with 37 seconds left in overtime, stealing the ball from Siakam for his third swipe of the night.\n\nAs Brown said after the game, Tatum \"woke up\" in overtime and scored 10 points to close the game. He hit a big three of his own (after missing one near the end of regulation) with 42.8 seconds left to essentially break Indy's back.\n\nTatum led all scorers with 36 points to go with a dozen rebounds. Brown finished with 26 points, seven rebounds, and five assists. They weren't perfect, but they stepped up big when they had to.\n\nJrue Holiday was a boss\n\nThis game was the exact reason every contender dreamt of adding Holiday over the summer. The veteran was as cool as a cucumber as havoc played out on the court, scoring 20 of his 28 points after halftime. Fresh off his All-Defensive second team nod efearlier in the afternoon, Holiday made a number of huge defensive plays in Game 1. In overtime, he bodied Haliburton on an in-bounds play and forced him to lose the ball out of bounds, setting up the possession that ended with Tatum's crushing three.\n\nIn addition to those 28 points, Holiday added eight assists, seven rebounds, and three steals to his ledger. He played 48 minutes on Tuesday, and was awesome for all of them. Simply awesome.\n\nThe Celtics got to the free-throw line\n\nThe Celtics did a great job waiting out Indiana's defense and drawing fouls. Boston got to the line 30 times in Game 1, scoring 24 points at the charity stripe.\n\nTatum was 10-for-12 at the line, matching his postseason-high for trips to the free-throw line. Brown worked his way into eight freebies on the night, but hit only five of them.\n\nIf the Pacers are going to let the Celtics attack the rim and send them to the line, Boston should keep taking advantage of it.\n\nThey found a way\n\nWas it pretty? No, absolutely not. But to win a title, you have to win ugly at times. A lot of people questioned if the Celtics could win ugly heading into this series, and if they had what it took to win close games.\n\nDespite putting themselves in a precarious position at the end of regulation, they found a way to rise from the dead and win Game 1. In the end, that should give the players a little more confidence, and make us feel a little bit better about the team.\n\nGoing cold in the fourth quarter\n\nAfter Holiday gave the Celtics a 104-101 lead by tipping in his own miss with with 7:29 left, the Celtics went over three minutes without points. Boston went 0-for-4 from the floor with two Brown turnovers before White ended the drought with a three at the 4:14 mark.\n\nThe Celtics had two offensive rebounds over that stretch, and missed both second-chance looks. Usually going that cold at that point in the game would sink a team. The Celtics were lucky they were able to overcome that stretch.\n\nFinishing quarters\n\nOn a number of occasions it felt like the Celtics were one make or one stop away from really blowing the game open. But each time that opportunity surfaced, they let Indiana get right back into the contest.\n\nAfter going up 29-20 near the end of the first quarter, the Celtics let the Pacers score six straight points. The two teams traded buckets before Obi Toppin ended the frame with a layup, and Boston led by just four points going into the second quarter.\n\nThe Celtics were up by eight points with less than five minutes left in the second quarter, but went into the locker room with the game tied, 64-64. They held a 13-point lead with 4:15 to go in the third quarter, but then let the Pacers go on a 16-4 run and held just a one-point lead going into the fourth. We've already touched on their cold spell in the fourth quarter.\n\nThey even tried to blow it at one point in overtime, when a bad pass by Tatum was picked off by Haliburton, followed by White fouling the Pacers star while he shot a three. His three freebies gave Indiana a 123-121 edge with 1:48 left, but that was the last time the Pacers held a lead.\n\nThe Celtics just got too comfortable after building a lead and put things on cruise control. They should know better than that against a team like the Pacers that can put points up in a hurry. Hopefully Tuesday night was the only reminder they'll need.\n\nThe Boston bench had a rough night\n\nPayton Pritchard provided a spark in the first quarter and had eight points off the bench, but was a minus-15 over his 23 minutes. Luke Kornet looked lost on defense for large stretches, and the Pacers attacked him at will. Sam Hauser played only nine minutes, but he missed both of his shots, turned the ball over, was whistled for a foul, and was a minus-8.\n\nThe Celtics got just 13 points from their bench in Game 1. Toppin scored 15 all by himself off the Indy bench, while T.J. McConnell put in 16 points off 6-for-11 shooting.\n\nPritchard will get more chances to hit shots, but Joe Mazzulla may have to look elsewhere on the bench for some much-needed production from his second unit. If Xavier Tillman is available on Thursday night, look for him to get some more run over Kornet.", "source": {"uri": "cbsnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": They failed to go up 2-0 on the Miami Heat in the first round, then had to settle for a 1-1 series against the Cleveland Cavaliers in the semifinals.\n\n\"We just gotta be prepared,\" Boston star Jaylen Brown said. \"We know it. We've seen it. We've been hearing it. Now we just have to come out and execute and be better. We will.\"\n\nGame 2 of the Eastern Conference finals is scheduled for Thursday in Boston.\n\nJayson Tatum collected a game-high 36 points and 12 rebounds in Boston's Game 1 victory against Indiana. He scored 10 points in overtime, including five straight that gave the Celtics a 127-123 lead with 42.9 seconds to play.\n\nJrue Holiday added 28 points and Mr. Brown finished with 26 for Boston. Andrew Nembhard canned a 3-pointer to put the Pacers up 115-110 with 1:57 remaining in the fourth quarter, but then the Celtics took over.\n\nMr. Holiday converted a layup and Mr. Brown sank two free throws to get Boston within one, 115-114, with 57.4 seconds to go. Mr. Nembhard stemmed the tide with a jumper, and Indiana took its 117-114 edge into what was originally supposed to be the game's final seconds.\n\nBut Mr. Brown knocked down a trey from the corner, knotting things at 117 with 6.1 seconds on the clock. Indiana star guard Tyrese Haliburton missed a 3-pointer at the buzzer, sending the contest to overtime.\n\nThree free throws from Ms. Haliburton in the extra session put the Pacers ahead 123-121 with 1:46 left, but Mr. Tatum answered with a three-point play, and the Celtics never gave up the lead the rest of the way.\n\nMr. Haliburton had 25 points and 10 assists. Pascal Siakam finished with 24 points, 12 rebounds and seven assists for the sixth-seeded Pacers, who received 23 points from Myles Turner.\n\n\"Our guys just need to concentrate on fighting the way they fought in (Game 1) from start to finish, and we'll be back Thursday,\" Indiana coach Rick Carlisle said. \"We did a lot of good things that we need to continue to do. We've been a tough-minded and resilient team, really for almost the entire second half of the year. We have to continue with that and come back here on Thursday night.\"\n\nIndiana made 9 of 10 free throws in the game. Boston was 24-for-30 from the foul line. (Reuters)\n\nThe Pacers committed 22 turnovers that led to 32 Celtics points.\n\nThe Celtics led 34-31 after one quarter, and it was 64-64 at halftime. The Pacers used a 9-0 spurt to pull within four points, 92-88, late in the third quarter, and they trailed 94-93 entering the fourth.\n\n\"They scored a lot of points in transition,\" Brown said. \"We gotta clean that up. We want to get them in a half-court game as much as possible.\n\n\"Defense is where we have to hang our hat. We have to make sure we execute on defense and the majority of it is transition -- getting back in transition. No layups.
