{"uri": "8139841911", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "07:21:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T07:21:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T07:20:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2024/may/22/tatums-36-carries-celtics-in-game-1/", "title": "Tatum's 36 carries Celtics in Game 1", "body": "BOSTON -- Jayson Tatum scored 36 points, including 10 in overtime after Jaylen Brown's tying three-pointer with 6.1 seconds remaining in regulation, and the Boston Celtics rallied just in time for a 133-128 victory over the Indiana Pacers on Tuesday night in Game 1 of the NBA Eastern Conference finals.\n\nJrue Holiday added a season-high 28 points and Brown finished with 26.\n\nGame 2 is Thursday night in Boston.\n\nTyrese Haliburton had 25 points and 10 assists for the Pacers, who made 13 three-pointers and scored 56 points in the lane against a Celtics team still playing without 7-footer Kristaps Porzingis.\n\nBut Boston dialed up its defense, finishing with 11 steals -- three each by Brown, Tatum and Holiday. The Celtics become the first team in NBA playoff history to have three players record 25 points and three steals in a game.\n\n\"We keep talking about protecting home court,\" Celtics forward Al Horford said. \"It's whatever it takes.\"\n\nPascal Siakam added 24 points and 12 rebounds. Myles Turner finished with 23 points and 10 rebounds for the sixth-seeded Pacers, who twice turned it over with a three-point lead in the final 30 seconds of regulation.\n\nBrown made them pay for the second one, hitting a three-pointer from the corner with Siakam in his face to tie it at 117-117.\n\n\"Jaylen had great balance,\" Celtics Coach Joe Mazzulla said. \"Great pass, great shot.\"\n\nPacers Coach Rick Carlisle said the loss was \"totally on me\" for not calling a timeout to advance the ball before their turnover that set up Brown's shot.\n\nAsked about the 21 turnovers Indiana committed, Haliburton said many of them were preventable.\n\n\"I think it's more on us,\" he said. \"I just felt like more of them were probably on us than them forcing turnovers.\"\n\nThe Celtics are now 2-2 in the playoffs when their opponent scores 100 or more points.\n\n\"I think we always knew that there's always a chance. We've seen crazy stuff happen all the time,\" Holiday said. \"I don't think that we think we lost the game until we actually lost the game and that's part of the reason why we were so resilient.\"\n\nIndiana went back ahead 123-121 when Haliburton hit all three free throws after being fouled with 1:46 remaining. Tatum then muscled in a layup and was fouled by T.J. McConnell. He completed the three-point play to put Boston ahead for good.\n\nThe Pacers turned it over again, this time by Haliburton. The ball found its way to Tatum at the top of key. He pumped, sidestepped a defender and sunk a three-pointer to make it 127-123 with 43 seconds left.\n\nDerrick White and Siakam traded layups. Holiday was fouled and hit two free throws to give Boston a 131-125 cushion.\n\n\"It's unfortunate we did so many good things in this game that it came down to a couple of mistakes at the end, but it's the NBA playoffs,\" Carlisle said. \"We've got to learn from it and we've got to bounce back\"\n\nBoston Celtics guard Jaylen Brown (7) dunks the ball against Indiana Pacers forward Aaron Nesmith (23) during the first quarter of Game 1 of the NBA Eastern Conference basketball finals, Tuesday, May 21, 2024, in Boston. {"uri": "8140612198", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "15:15:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T15:15:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T15:15:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/tyrese-haliburton-pacers-belong-with-celtics/", "title": "Tyrese Haliburton: Pacers 'Belong' With Celtics After Game 1", "body": "The Pacers had the top-seeded Celtics on the ropes, but Boston found a way to survive in the end.\n\nHighlights The Indiana Pacers nearly pulled off an upset against the Boston Celtics in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference Finals. Pacers star Tyrese Haliburton remains confident that they belong at this stage against Boston. Indiana faltered in regulation and the Celtics took advantage in overtime.\n\nGame 1 was right there for the taking for the Indiana Pacers. Unfortunately, poor execution late in regulation doomed them on Tuesday night and the Boston Celtics found a way to survive and win Game 1 in overtime to take a 1-0 lead in the Eastern Conference Finals.\n\nA loss like that could have demoralized a young team like Indiana. But the Pacers' young star Tyrese Haliburton continued to exude confidence that he and his group are fine and should continue to give the top-seeded Celtics a run for their money in this series.\n\n\"We know we can play with these guys. There are a lot of people out here saying we don't belong here. We don't really care. We know we belong.\"\n\nIndiana had plenty of naysayers entering the Eastern Conference Finals, but given how they played in the series-opener, the Pacers certainly proved they belong on this stage.\n\nPacers Nearly Upset the Celtics in Game 1 Indiana had Boston on the ropes\n\nThe Celtics threw the early haymakers in Game 1, going on a 12-0 run to start the game. But the Pacers remained resilient and managed to weather the early storm from Boston.\n\nThat essentially became the story throughout the majority of the series opener. The Celtics led by as much as 13 points in the second half before Indiana closed the third quarter with a 13-1 run to cut the deficit to one point heading into the final frame.\n\nThe game became a track meet in the fourth quarter. Indiana eventually gained the advantage as it went into crunch time. Pascal Siakam and Andrew Nembhard made multiple big plays down the stretch that swung the momentum towards the Pacers' favor.\n\nThe Pacers had the Celtics on the ropes and looked well on their way to a Game 1 upset when they had a three-point lead and the ball with 10 seconds remaining in regulation.\n\nAll they needed to do was finish out the game with freethrows.\n\nCeltics Hit Haymakers Late in Game 1 Boston's experience came through in the clutch\n\nHowever, Indiana's inexperience and Boston's resiliency surfaced in the end. The Pacers committed multiple miscues late in the game that ultimately cost them the series-opener.\n\nThey turned the ball over with 10 seconds to go, which opened the door for Jaylen Brown to knock down a tough game-tying three-pointer that sent the game into overtime.\n\nThe extra session then gave Jayson Tatum a chance to redeem himself after a discouraging fourth quarter. Tatum scored 10 of Boston's 16 points in the period, which included the dagger three-pointer that put the Celtics up by four with 42 seconds remaining.\n\nThat was essentially all she wrote for Indiana in Game 1. But despite the loss, Haliburton was still encouraged by how they played for 47 minutes before they faltered in the end.\n\n\"We'll go back, watch the film. There will be good, there will be bad. We'll learn from it and we'll be a lot better in Game 2.\"\n\nHaliburton and the Pacers will have their chance to tie the Eastern Conference Finals on Thursday in Boston.\n\nRelated Pacers' Rick So we have got to come out and be better,\" he added.\n\nThe Pacers came into the game on the back of a gruelling game seven win against the New York Knicks on Sunday and Boston were the fastest out of the traps.\n\nWith the loud home crowd sensing Indiana were struggling, Al Horford's 26-foot three pointer made it 12-0.\n\nThe Pacers got back into the game and levelled it 64-64 at half-time.\n\nA 13-point run in the third put Boston 87-77 up but again Indiana came back and with less than two minutes to go they led 115-100.\n\nCostly turnovers\n\nIndiana turned the ball over twice in the final 30 seconds of regulation before Brown's crucial three pointer, over the top of Siakam.\n\nWhen Haliburton was unable to get off a last-gasp shot the game went to overtime.\n\nA step back three-pointer from Tatum with 43 left put Boston four points up.\n\nAfter Derrick White's layup extended the advantage to six with 25 seconds left, the game was beyond the Pacers.\n\n\"We were able to make some plays at the end but we have got to be better to be honest, but I'll take the win,\" said Brown.\n\nPacers head coach Rick Carlisle said he was to blame for allowing the Celtics to take the game to overtime.\n\n\"The loss is totally on me,\" he said.\n\n\"With 10 seconds left in regulation, we should have just taken the time out, advanced the ball and found a way to get it in and made a free throw or two and ended the game.\n\n\"But it didn't happen and we made some other mistakes,\" he added, referring to the team's turnover problems.\n\n\"We know we made mistakes and that is an area we have got to clean up,\" said Carlisle.\n\n\"We have been a tough-minded, resilient team for almost the entire second half of the year but we have to continue with that and come back Tyrese Haliburton said the Pacers played great for 47 minutes but didn't \"sustain\" it 48. Pacers showed great resilience in Game 1, but may regret not closing out Game 1 in Boston.\n\nThe Indiana Pacers needed one more minute of great play to steal a Game 1 win over the Boston Celtics.\n\nUnfortunately, they came up just short.\n\nThe Pacers lost Game 1 of the Eastern Conference Finals in heartbreaking fashion, blowing a late lead in the final minute to allow the Celtics to force overtime. Indiana had their chances in overtime, but couldn't keep up with the Celtics offense, as they fell, 133-128.\n\nAfter the game, Pacers star guard Tyrese Haliburton said the Pacers know they can hang with the Celtics and just need to focus on closing out after playing 47 \"great\" minutes in Game 1.\n\n\"Today we played great for about 47 minutes and just didn't sustain it for 48,\" - Tyrese Haliburton\n\nHaliburton said the Pacers had been \"trash\" in Game 1s in their first-round series against the Milwaukee Bucks and second-round series against the New York Knicks, calling Tuesday's game an improvement.\n\nWild Finish Between Pacers & Celtics in Game 1 Pacers and Celtics both had crucial turnovers in key moments late\n\nUnfortunately, Haliburton had a heavy hand in the Pacers' meltdown. Haliburton dribbled the ball out of bounds with 27 seconds to play in regulation and the Pacers leading by three. Though that play didn't lead directly to a Celtics basket, it did cost the Pacers the opportunity to run the clock down and perhaps get fouled by the Celtics.\n\nAfter Jaylen Brown hit a wild, game-tying three-pointer in the corner with six seconds to play, the Pacers still had a chance to win the game. However, Haliburton turned down several looks from deep while evading Celtics defenders and only got off a tough, well-contested shot as he fell out of bounds as time expired. Haliburton said he should have gotten a better final shot and that it had already replayed in his head over and over.\n\nHaliburton also had a costly turnover in overtime, as he lost control of the ball while being guarded by Jrue Holiday with 1:02 remaining and the Celtics up one. Jayson Tatum responded on the other end with a three-pointer that put the Celtics up four and for good.\n\n\"I had two bad turnovers that I feel like cost us the game ... I gotta be better and I will be better in Game 2,\" Haliburton said.\n\nHaliburton rued the unforced turnovers, calling them \"frustrating, to say the least.\"\n\nHaliburton also rejected the premise that the Pacers should feel \"encouraged\" by hanging with the Celtics. Haliburton said the Pacers know they can play with Boston, and that the team has ignored critics who have questioned whether Indiana would be in the conference finals if their previous two opponents hadn't been dealing with major injuries.\n\nIndiana did show great fight in Game 1. They looked to be up against the ropes in the opening minutes, when the Celtics stormed out to a 12-0 lead. Indiana responded and ended the quarter down only three. The Celtics also made a run in the third quarter to go up by 13, only for the Pacers to fight back within one point by the end of the quarter.\n\nThe Pacers have plenty to feel good about, including a 30-10 free throw disparity in favor of the Celtics.\n\nOf course, Boston didn't play a full 48 minutes, either. Whether Indiana comes to regret not closing out Game 1 will be a major storyline in the series going forward.\n\nRelated Jaylen Brown Says Jayson Tatum 'Finally Woke Up' Late in Celtics' Game 1 Win {"uri": "8141055273", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "21:27:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T21:27:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T21:14:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13449189/Celtics-Pacers-try-overcome-bad-habits-heading-Game-2-East-finals.html", "title": "Celtics and Pacers will try to overcome bad habits heading to Game...", "body": "BOSTON (AP) - There was a dominant refrain ringing in Jayson Tatum\u00b4s head following the Celtics\u00b4 comeback 133-128 overtime win over the Pacers to open the Eastern Conference finals.\n\n\"Don\u00b4t relax,\" he said.\n\nIn each of the previous two rounds, Boston opened its series with Miami and Cleveland with lopsided victories, only to then lose Game 2.\n\nThe Pacers have experienced the opposite, dropping Game 1 in Rounds 1 and 2 and then having to regroup to overtake Milwaukee and New York.\n\nTyrese Haliburton\u00b4s takeaway from Indiana\u00b4s latest Game 1 setback against the East\u00b4s top seed? Be disappointed. But don\u00b4t fret.\n\n\"We know we can play with these guys,\" Haliburton said. \"There\u00b4s a lot of people out there saying we don\u00b4t belong here. We don\u00b4t really care. (AP Photo/Michael Dwyer)\n\nWhat\u00b4s clear is that how both teams adjust for Game 2 on Thursday night will set the tone for the balance of this series.\n\nRecent history aside, the similarities between the Celtics and Pacers were on display throughout Game 1.\n\nBoth teams thrived offensively this season and did so again, combining for 261 points Tuesday night. It was the highest scoring game of this postseason and the most in a conference finals game since Boston and Detroit totaled 264 in Game 4 of the 1987 East finals.\n\nWhat was also on display were both teams\u00b4 vulnerabilities. Indiana exploited Boston\u00b4s weakened interior defense throughout, racking up 56 points in the paint. But the Celtics ultimately prevailed, benefiting from a myriad of mistakes by a young Pacers team short on playoff experience.\n\nHaliburton had two key turnovers to help the Celtics rebound from a five-point deficit in the final two minutes of regulation. First, he dribbled off his foot as he was bringing the ball up the floor with less than 30 seconds remaining in a three-point game. He also fumbled the ball out of bounds with just over a minute to play in OT.\n\nThe two miscues were part of 22 turnovers on the night for a Pacers team that came in averaging fewer than 12 per game in these playoffs.\n\nIt\u00b4s part of the growing pains Indiana coach Rick Carlisle expected his youth-heavy team would have to endure during this playoff run.\n\n\"You have to go through it to really experience what it\u00b4s all about,\" Carlisle said. \"We try to help prepare them for those experiences. But there\u00b4s nothing like going through it.\"\n\nLikewise, Boston learned in Game 1 that it can expect to continue to be pushed by an underdog Pacers team that has the depth to keep up with the Celtics.\n\nIndiana got the usual contributions of Haliburton, Pascal Siakam and Myles Turner, who combined for 72 points. But the Pacers also got a huge lift from reserves Obi Toppin (15 points) and T.J. McConnell (13 points), who helped Indiana\u00b4s reserve outscore its Boston counterparts 30-13.\n\nIt\u00b4s yet another wrinkle that makes the Pacers a hard team to prepare for, Celtics coach Joe Mazzulla said.\n\n\"With their ability to play different lineups, the way they sub - they sub two or three different guys at a time. They are willing to go away from sub patterns for certain guys,\" Mazzulla said. \"You have to be wary of going to any and everything at any particular time. ... Anything is on the table versus a team like this because of their versatility.\"\n\nTatum is expecting both teams to play with renewed confidence in Game 2.\n\n\"(Game 1) being a close game going into overtime they certainly feel like they probably should have won. And we feel like we can play a lot better,\" he said. \"So, I\u00b4m excited for us to come out and respond. {"uri": "8140526507", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "14:20:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T14:20:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T14:19:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://heavy.com/sports/nba/boston-celtics/the-boston-celtics-got-exactly-what-they-needed-against-the-pacers/", "title": "The Boston Celtics Got Exactly What They Needed Against the Pacers", "body": "Getty The Boston Celtics pulled out a Game 1 win over the Indiana Pacers.\n\nThe Boston Celtics raced out to a 12-0 lead against the Indiana Pacers in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference Finals on Tuesday, May 21. It took overtime, but the Celtics inched closer to a berth in the 2024 NBA Finals after a 133-128 victory at TD Garden.\n\nIt was a roller-coaster affair for Boston. At times, the Celtics looked sharp and hungry. Other times, they looked sluggish and careless. In any case, they ran their record to 9-2 in the postseason and got the Game 1 victory. More importantly, they got exactly what they needed.\n\nIn Boston's previous eight postseason victories this year, only one was by 10 points or less. Even their two losses were blowouts. The Celtics hadn't been in a game that came down to the wire. Game 1 against the Pacers did.\n\nDespite jumping out to the early lead, the Celtics and Pacers were tied at halftime. The Pacers even tattled off the first five points of the second half to take a 69-64 lead. Boston led by as many as 13 in the third quarter, but the lead never felt safe.\n\nThe Pacers had a chance to put the game away late, but turned the ball over with a three-point lead. Jaylen Brown then sent the game into overtime with an in-your-face 3-pointer. Boston outscored Indiana 16-11 in the extra session to pull out the win.\n\nIt's a victory the Celtics probably wouldn't have pulled out a year ago. Age, experience, and maturity took over against the young Pacers.\n\nCeltics star Jayson Tatum, who scored 36 points and had 12 rebounds, called the game \"chaos.\" Chaos is exactly what the doctor ordered for Boston.\n\n\"That (expletive) was chaos,\" Tatum told reporters after the game. \"That (expletive) was wild. Just stay present. Stay in the moment.\n\n\"As long as there's time on the clock, and the game is within reach, we feel like we have a chance. This core group has been in so many big-time games, big-time moments, where we've had a lead, lost it and still won or been down and figured out a way to win. I've had a lot of crazy endings in this building. In a weird way, we've been there before. We always believe.\"\n\nPacers coach Rick Carlisle took full responsibility for the loss, but in the end, Indiana committed 21 turnovers, including several in key moments. One of those came in the final seconds with the Packers holding a lead. It set up Brown's late-game heroics.\n\n\"This loss is totally on me,\" Carlisle said at his postgame press conference. \"With 10 seconds left in regulation, we should've just taken the timeout, advanced the ball, and found a way to get it in and make a free throw or two and end the game. It didn't happen.\"\n\nVeteran guard Jrue Holiday, in his first season with the Celtics, made an impact on both sides of the ball. He finished with a season-high 28 points and was locked in defensively, collecting three steals.\n\n\"We had a lot of turnovers that would be hard to explain,\" Carlisle said, \"but this is conference finals in the NBA playoffs.\"\n\nIt was a gut-wrenching win for the Celtics, but it was the kind they desperately needed.", "source": {"uri": "heavy.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Heavy"}, {"uri": "8140281010", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "11:48:11", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T11:48:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T11:47:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.boston.com/sports/boston-celtics/2024/05/22/jaylen-browns-heroics-vault-celtics-over-pacers-chaotic-game-1-10-takeaways/", "title": "Jaylen Brown's heroics vault Celtics over Pacers in chaotic Game 1: 10 takeaways", "body": "The Celtics relied on their stars to pull off a 133-128 overtime victory over the Pacers in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference Finals Tuesday.\n\nThe Celtics needed a little luck and a gutsy performance down the stretch, but they pulled out a 133-128 overtime victory over the Pacers in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference Finals on Tuesday.\n\nHere are the takeaways.\n\n1. It's hard to explain how the Celtics were even in a position to win in the first place, but we'll do our best.\n\nOne thing to know about this series is that it will be very stressful for both teams. The Pacers are not a good defensive group, but they can really score. That means there will be stretches where the Celtics go up by double figures, and moments shortly afterward when the Pacers come roaring back. There might very well be times when the Pacers go up by double figures, but Celtics fans shouldn't despair: There's a good chance they will come roaring back as well.\n\nOn Tuesday, the Celtics held a 13-point lead in the second half, and a five-point lead in overtime, but the Pacers - predictably - rallied, and they held a three-point lead and possession of the ball with 37 seconds remaining after Jayson Tatum missed a makeable 3-pointer. Things looked bleak for the Celtics.\n\nBut the wheels came off entirely for the Pacers. Tyrese Haliburton turned the ball over by dribbling it off his knee. The Pacers got a stop, and after an ill-advised and unnecessary turnaround jumper by Tatum in the paint with 16 seconds remaining, the Pacers had another chance to put the game away up three. Things looked very bleak for the Celtics.\n\nBut once again, the Pacers threw away their opportunity. This time, Nembhard panicked up against a five-second call, and Jaylen Brown made a spectacular play disrupting Nembhard's pass to a streaking Pascal Siakam. Siakam couldn't grab it before it went out of bounds, and the Celtics had one more chance.\n\nThat set up this moment.\n\n\"Before the inbound I was talking to myself,\" Brown said. \"'If I get this shot, it's going in.' I was telling myself the whole time, you get it, it's going up and it's going in. I happened to create some space on the backside and was able to make a big-time play.\"\n\n\"It's simple,\" Tatum added. \"Big-time players make big-time plays. That was a hell of a shot he made. The deflection that gave us the opportunity to make that shot.\"\n\nIn overtime, Tatum took the wheel. The Celtics trailed by two with 1:20 remaining, but Tatum scored a layup and was fouled by T.J. McConnell, and he buried a 3-pointer on the next possession that pushed the lead to four with 43 seconds left. The Celtics held on for a wild 1-0 series lead.\n\n\"Just staying with it, man,\" Joe Mazzulla said. \"You can't have any expectations about how it's supposed to go. You miss a layup, you miss a three, you give something up, it doesn't matter. I thought our guys had that kind of mindset, and credit to him for just changing the frequency.\"\n\n2. The discussion around Tatum will be fascinating over the next few days. On the one hand, he missed two big shots - the potential game-tying triple and his turnaround jumper with 16 seconds left, which really was a terrible shot. If the Pacers hadn't lost control of their limbs, he never would have had a chance to be the overtime hero. Even in overtime, he was a little shaky - his turnover with 1:30 left led to three free throws by Tyrese Haliburton, which allowed the Pacers to regain the lead.\n\nOn the other hand, well, the Pacers did lose control of their limbs, and Tatum was the overtime hero.\n\n\"That s -- was chaos,\" Tatum said. \"That s -- was wild. But just stay present, stay in the moment. As long as there's time still on the clock and the game is within reach, we feel like we have a chance. This core group has been in so many big-time games, big-time moments.\"\n\nIn the end, Tatum scored 11 of his 36 points in overtime and finished with a 36-12-4 stat line with three steals.\n\n3. Brown, meanwhile, scored 26 points on 10-for-20 shooting to go with seven rebounds, five assists and three steals. As is often the case, he got the Celtics off to a great start offensively with 10 points on 5-for-6 shooting in the first quarter.\n\nThe Celtics needed everything from their stars, and both stars came through in a big way at the last possible second.\n\n4. Jrue Holiday had one of his best games of the postseason with 28 points on 10-for-16 shooting and a number of nice defensive plays. Haliburton will have to work for his offense throughout the series against Holiday, and he'll have to give a little more than he appears comfortable giving on the defensive end - Holiday dominated opposing guards in the post and went at Haliburton at every available opportunity.\n\n\"He was unbelievable tonight,\" Al Horford said. \"It was a lot of fun watching him just kind of go and do his thing and just put his imprint on the game. Whether it's posting up or whether it's shooting threes. He was just all over the place.\"\n\n5. The Celtics could really use Kristaps Porzingis in this series. The Pacers gave up a lot of pick-and-pop 3-pointers, and Horford struggled to take advantage consistently - he finished 3-for-12 from behind the arc. Porzingis would stress an already-stressed Pacers defense to a breaking point.\n\nThe good news? The Celtics seem to have some momentum on that front.\n\n6. Horford had a difficult game defensively - the Pacers targeted him in the pick-and-roll with some success, especially late as they tried to put the game away.\n\n\"It's hard to tell right now because the way that I prepared for the shots, that at least that I felt like I gave up, were the shots that I can be okay with the results,\" Horford said. \"Played good defense, mid-range pull up jump shots. But I definitely will go back and look at it. And even in that regard, I want to be better. So, I'll make sure that I'm better defensively for this next game.\"\n\n7. Sam Hauser missed both of his 3-point attempts and had a couple of really rough sequences, including one in the second half where he gave up a jumper to McConnell before setting an illegal screen that gave the Pacers the ball back for a final shot. Haliburton nailed a 3-pointer.\n\nHauser played nine minutes and was -8.\n\n8. This is a difficult series for Luke Kornet as well: The Pacers targeted him with pick-and-pops for Myles Turner, who shot 9-for-13 from the floor and 3-for-4 from three to finish with 23 points. With Xavier Tillman out for personal reasons, the Celtics needed to figure out a way to make it work, and they shuffled things in the second half enough to flip Kornet's -4 in the first half to a +6 in the final two quarters.\n\n9. After four quarters, the Celtics held a 23-3 advantage in free throws. They finished with 30 to the Pacers' 10.\n\nRick Carlisle opted not to complain postgame, citing the amount of money he has already lost on complaining about officials.\n\nFor what it's worth, that disparity is odd, but the Celtics were called for just 16.2 fouls per game during the regular season (second-fewest in the NBA) while the Pacers were whistled for 21.4 (most in the NBA). So while 23-3 is ... lopsided to say the least, there's reason to believe the Pacers will commit more fouls than the Celtics over the course of this series naturally.\n\n10. Game 2 will tip off at 8 p.m. on Thursday.\n\n\"[This game] doesn't prove anything,\" Tatum said. \"We won a big time game. Series is far from over. We got to come back and play well enough to win again on Thursday. I'm not trying to prove anything individually. I know the ultimate goal is to try to win a championship, but one step at a time. It's a big-time win tonight and come back and be ready for Thursday.\"", "source": {"uri": "boston.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Boston"}, "authors": [{"uri": "tom_westerholm@boston.com", "name": "Tom Westerholm", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyrese_Haliburton", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Tyrese Haliburton"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA_Conference_Finals", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "NBA Conference Finals"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indiana_Pacers", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Indiana Pacers"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston_Celtics", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Boston Celtics"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Overtime_(sports)", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Overtime (sports)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Nembhard", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Andrew Nembhard"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pascal_Siakam", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Pascal Siakam"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jayson_Tatum", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Jayson Tatum"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaylen_Brown", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Jaylen Brown"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jrue_Holiday", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Jrue Holiday"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Layup", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Layup"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al_Horford", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Al Horford"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Mazzulla", "type": "person", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Joe Mazzulla"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T._J._McConnell", "type": "person", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "T. David Butler II-USA TODAY Sports via REUTERS\n\nJayson Tatum scored a game-high 36 points and added 12 rebounds as the Boston Celtics earned a 133-128 overtime victory against the visiting Indiana Pacers on Tuesday night in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference finals.\n\nTatum scored 10 points in overtime, including six straight that gave the top-seeded Celtics a 127-123 lead with 42.9 seconds to play.\n\nJrue Holiday added 28 points and Jaylen Brown finished with 26 points in the win. After Brown drained a corner 3-pointer that made it 117-117 with 6.1 to play in regulation, Tyrese Haliburton missed a 3-pointer at the buzzer and the game went to overtime.\n\nHaliburton had 25 points and 10 assists, and Pascal Siakam finished with 24 points, 12 rebounds and seven assists for the Pacers. Myles Turner added 23 points in the loss.\n\nIndiana made 9 of 10 free throws in the game. Boston was 24 for 30 from the free-throw line.\n\nThe Pacers committed 22 turnovers.\n\nThe Celtics scored the game's first 12 points and led 34-31 after one quarter. Boston had a 47-37 lead after Holiday's jump shot with 8:01 remaining in the second quarter. Indiana tied the score, 61-61, on Haliburton's 3-pointer with 1:19 left in the half. It was 64-64 at halftime.\n\nTurner led all scorers with 18 points in the first half.\n\nIndiana had its first lead of the game after Haliburton's layup broke a 64-64 tie with 11:25 remaining in the third quarter. The Pacers stretched their lead to five, but Boston regained control and led 87-75 after Tatum's three-point play with 4:50 left in the third capped a 13-0 run.\n\nThe Pacers used a 9-0 spurt to pull within four points, 92-88, late in the third. {"uri": "2024-05-364834780", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "16:04:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T16:04:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T13:40:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.philstar.com/sports/2024/05/23/2357158/celtics-draw-first-blood", "title": "Celtics draw first blood", "body": "Brown forges extra time, Tatum delivers clincher\n\nLOS ANGELES - The Boston Celtics needed a late rally to force overtime against the Indiana Pacers before emerging with a 133-128 win in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference Finals on Tuesday.\n\nBoston's Jaylen Brown sank a three-pointer from the corner with 6.1 seconds remaining to tie the score at 117-117 and take it to overtime.\n\nThen Jayson Tatum made a crucial late three-pointer to push the Celtics to victory and a 1-0 lead in the best-of-seven series.\n\nTatum top scored for Boston with 36 points, 10 of them in overtime, collecting 12 rebounds and four assists with Brown putting up 26 and Jrue Holiday 28.\n\nIndiana, who fought back from large deficits several times in the game, were led by Tyrese Haliburton's 25 points, 10 assists and three rebounds with Pascal Siakam making 24 points, seven assists and 12 rebounds.\n\nBrown was far from happy with the performance from Boston, who had almost a week off after their 4-1 series win over Cleveland.\n\n\"A lot of ups and downs, I don't think we played our best,\" said three-time All Star Brown.\n\n\"We almost dropped the game on our own floor. So we have got to come out and be better,\" he added.\n\nThe Pacers came into the game on the back of a gruelling Game 7 win against the New York Knicks on Sunday and Boston were the fastest out of the traps.\n\nWith the loud home crowd sensing Indiana were struggling, Al Horford's 26-foot three pointer made it 12-0.\n\nThe Pacers got back into the game and levelled it 64-64 at halftime.\n\nA 13-point run in the third put Boston 87-77 up but again Indiana came back and with less than two minutes to go they led 115-100.\n\nIndiana turned the ball over twice in the final 30 seconds of regulation before Brown's crucial three pointer, over the top of Siakam.\n\nWhen Haliburton was unable to get off a last-gasp shot the game went to overtime.\n\nA step back three-pointer from Tatum with 43 left put Boston four points up.\n\nAfter Derrick White's layup extended the advantage to six with 25 seconds left, the game was beyond the Pacers.\n\n\"We were able to make some plays at the end but we have got to be better to be honest, but I'll take the win,\" said Brown.\n\nPacers head coach Rick Carlisle said he was to blame for allowing the Celtics to take the game to overtime.\n\n\"The loss is totally on me,\" he said.\n\n\"With 10 seconds left in regulation, we should have just taken the time out, advanced the ball and found a way to get it in and made a free throw or two and ended the game.\n\n\"But it didn't happen and we made some other mistakes,\" he added, referring to the team's turnover problems.\n\n\"We know we made mistakes and that is an area we have got to clean up,\" said Carlisle.\n\n\"We have been a tough-minded, resilient team for almost the entire second half of the year but we have to continue with that and come back here on Thursday Pacers", "body": "BOSTON -- The Celtics started off the Eastern Conference finals on the right note, but it didn't come easy with Boston earning a 133-128 Game 1 win in overtime the Indiana Pacers on Tuesday night at TD Garden.\n\nThe Celtics took a 1-0 lead in the best-of-seven series.\n\nCheck out the full box score here.\n\nONE BIG TAKEAWAY\n\nNobody was giving the sixth-seeded Pacers a chance against the juggernaut Celtics heading into the conference finals.\n\nWell, the Pacers had something to say about that and still made a statement even though they came out on the losing end.\n\nThe Pacers were their usual pesky selves and continued to shoot the ball extremely well. Indiana challenged and pushed the Celtics at points and never backed down from Boston even when it start the game with a fury by scoring the first 12 points of the contest. The Pacers even overcame a 13-point deficit in the third quarter and remained unfazed during crunch time.\n\nThe same can't be said about the Celtics, who rushed 3-pointers at time in the final minutes. Jayson Tatum even missed a wide open triple that would have tied the game with under a minute left to play. But Jaylen Brown erased all of that with a shot from the corner that will live on in Celtics history if they go on to win the NBA title.\n\nThis will serve as a massive wake-up call to the Celtics. The Pacers aren't going to be a pushover like the Miami Heat and Cleveland Cavaliers. Boston showed its mettle when it mattered most, but it was supposed to be easier than this for the Celtics.\n\nSTARS OF THE GAME\n\n-- Brown rescued the Celtics in regulation. Brown knocked down a 3-pointer from the corner in front of Indiana's bench with six seconds left in the fourth quarter to level the score at 117-all. Brown finished with 26 points along with seven rebounds and five assists.\n\n-- Tyrese Haliburton was the catalyst for the Pacers. He scored a team-high 25 points and dished out 10 assists. Haliburton also had a couple of critical 3-pointers -- he hit six in the game -- including a logo trey near the end of the first half and a buzzer-beating triple to close out the third quarter. Haliburton also came up with a critical block on a Derrick White 3-point attempt late in the fourth quarter.\n\n-- Tatum came through in overtime to help push the Celtics across the finish line. The Celtics star netted a game-high 36 points on 12-for-26 shooting to go along with 12 rebounds and four assists.\n\nUP NEXT\n\nThe Celtics and Pacers square off in Game 2 of the conference finals Thursday night. {"uri": "2024-05-364560100", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "12:06:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T12:06:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T11:58:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.star-telegram.com/sports/article288629335.html", "title": "'Resilient' Celtics overcome Pacers in OT, win Game 1 of ECF", "body": "The Celtics forced 21 turnovers and scored 32 points off the giveaways in the 133-128 triumph Tuesday at TD Garden. Tatum logged 12 rebounds, four assists and three steals.\n\nGuard Jrue Holiday and Brown chipped in 28 and 26 points, respectively. The game featured 10 lead changes.\n\n\"We always knew that there's always a chance,\" Holiday told reporters. \"We've seen crazy stuff happen all the time. I don't think that we think we lost the game until we actually lost the game. And that's part of the reason why we were so resilient toward the end of the game.\n\n\"Like I said, anything can happen. A couple turnovers, a great shot, great look by [Brown] or on the other end, we make a couple other shots that were wide open and it could be a completely different game. So [we're] just the type of team that's going to keep on fighting no matter how long and no matter what it takes.\"\n\nThe Pacers outshot the Celtics 53.5% to 47.5%. They also held a 30-13 edge in bench points. Star guard Tyrese Haliburton logged 25 points, 10 assists, three rebounds and three steals in the loss. Forward Pascal Siakam and center Myles Turner scored 24 and 23 points, respectively, for the Pacers.\n\nThe Celtics went on a 12-0 run off the tip off and carried a 34-31 lead into the second quarter. They continued to hold the lead until the Pacers went on a 10-2 run and tied the score several times. The score was 64-64 at halftime.\n\nThe Pacers took their first lead off a 5-0 run to start the second half. The Celtics later responded with a 15-2 run to push their lead back to double digits. The Pacers then outscored their foes 14-2 over the final 2:39 of the third quarter, but still trailed 94-93 to start the fourth.\n\nThe Pacers and Celtics exchanged the lead twice over the next few minutes before the Pacers used a 7-0 run to jump ahead once again.\n\nThe Celtics trailed 117-114 with 47 seconds remaining. Tatum and Derrick White each missed key shots over the next several seconds before a Pacers turnover set up their final possession of regulation.\n\nHoliday threw an inbound pass from the baseline to start that sequence. Brown caught the feed in the left corner. He did a quick ball fake before launching a fadeaway shot, which fell in the net and tied the score with just 5.7 seconds remaining.\n\nHaliburton missed a 3-pointer on the next possession, sending the game to overtime.\n\nThe Pacers guard redeemed himself by making a shot from downtown for the first points of overtime. The Celtics answered with a 12-3 run, which included a string of eight-consecutive points from Tatum, to snatch back momentum for good.\n\n\"As long as there is time still on the clock and the game is still in reach, we feel like we have a chance,\" Brown said. \"This core group has been in so many big time games and big time moments. ... We always believe.\"\n\nThe top-seeded Celtics will host the No. 6 Pacers in Game 2 at 8 p.m. EDT Thursday in Boston. {"uri": "8139554404", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "03:20:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T03:20:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T03:19:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.bostonherald.com/2024/05/21/jaylen-brown-forces-ot-then-celtics-capture-game-1-in-thriller-over-pacers/", "title": "Jaylen Brown forces OT, then Celtics capture Game 1 in thriller over Pacers", "body": "Boston Celtics | Jaylen Brown forces OT, then Celtics capture Game 1 in thriller over Pacers\n\nAfter a pair of sleepy five-game playoff series, the Celtics kicked off the Eastern Conference finals with an electric overtime thriller Tuesday night at TD Garden.\n\nBoston was pushed to the brink by the lightning-paced, high-scoring Indiana Pacers, but Joe Mazzulla's squad survived, winning 133-128 to take a 1-0 lead in the best-of-seven series.\n\nJaylen Brown drilled a game-tying 3-pointer with 5.7 seconds remaining to force overtime, and Jayson Tatum scored nine of his game-high 36 points in the extra session to help the Celtics pull away.\n\nAll five Celtics starters finished with at least 15 points, with Jrue Holiday notching 28 on 10-of-16 shooting (4-for-8 from three) and Brown scoring 26. Holiday also added eight assists, seven rebounds and three steals in his best all-around performance of the postseason.\n\nHoliday, Tatum and Brown all played at least 44 minutes for Boston, which improved to 9-2 in the playoffs. Game 2 is Thursday night on Causeway Street.\n\nThe Celtics withstood a similarly balanced scoring output from the Pacers, who led the league in points per game during the regular season. Seven different Indiana players scored in double figures, with Tyrese Haliburton leading the way with 25 points and 10 assists.\n\nPacers head coach Rick Carlisle called the Celtics \"impossible\" to defend during his pregame news conference, and they looked that way in the opening minutes.\n\nA rim-rattling Brown dunk seconds into the game -- off a Tatum steal -- ignited an early 12-0 run for Boston that also included 3-pointers from Holiday and Al Horford.\n\nThe Pacers, two days removed from the best playoff shooting performance in NBA history in Game 7 against the Knicks, missed their first six shots before finding their stroke. Indiana quickly trimmed Boston's lead and trailed 34-31 at the start of the second quarter, buoyed by 11 first-quarter points off the bench Obi Toppin.\n\nIndiana found success targeting Boston's backups during that flurry, scoring against Payton Pritchard and Sam Hauser on three successive possessions. But Pritchard with responded one 3-pointer late in the first and another early in the second, then pulled out a nifty juke to hit a midrange jumper over T.J. McConnell.\n\nThe Celtics built their lead back to double digits four minutes into the second quarter, but difficulties defending big man Myles Turner caused that to swiftly evaporate. Turner scored 12 straight points for the Pacers, all with Horford off the floor, exploiting a one-sided matchup against backup Celtics center Luke Kornet.\n\nKornet typically is Boston's third option when starting big Kristaps Porzingis is healthy. Porzingis reportedly could return as Game 4 of this series, but he's missed the last seven games with a calf strain.\n\nKornet was better in his second-half minutes, though, and was a plus-2 for the game, compared to minus-8 and minus-15 for fellow backups Hauser and Pritchard, respectively.\n\nA dunk by ex-Celtic Aaron Nesmith pulled Indiana even with 2:43 remaining in the half, and the teams proceeded to trade clutch threes in the final second, with Haliburton countering White's second-chance trey with a towering 35-footer. The two high-octane squads entered halftime tied at 64-64.\n\nBoth shot better than 50% from the floor over the first two frames, but the Pacers owned a clear edge from beyond the arc (53.3% to Boston's 31.8%) after their shaky start.\n\nBrown, Tatum and White all were in double figures for Boston at half.\n\nFive quick points from Haliburton out of the break gave Indiana its first lead of the night, but the Celtics responded with a 7-0 run to vault back ahead. After a Horford three, Brown slithered past Turner for a layup, then forced a turnover at the other end to spring Tatum in transition.\n\nWhite, Brown and Holiday then powered a 16-2 run that gave Boston its largest lead yet, 90-77. The Celtics succeeded in attacking the basket during that spurt, drawing five fouls in a span of eight possessions, and Brown delivered a defensive highlight when he swatted a Nesmith 3-pointer into the Boston bench.\n\nNesmith, Boston's first-round pick in 2020, finished with 14 points and four turnovers and fouled out in overtime.\n\nThe Celtics missed five of their 13 free throws in the third quarter, however, keeping Indiana within striking distance. And again, the Pacers rallied. Down 92-79 late in the third, they ripped off eight straight points, then cut the deficit to one with an off-balance, buzzer-beating three by Haliburton.\n\nSeconds into the fourth, it was 95-94 Pacers. The Celtics pulled back ahead on a Tatum jumper and led by five after 10 straight points from Tatum and Holiday, but Indiana drew even again on a Turner three with 5:43 remaining.\n\nIndiana led by three with a minute remaining. Two Brown free throws cut that to one, but Aaron Nembhard hit a stepback over Horford on the next possession. After Tatum missed a straightaway three that would have tied the game with 14.1 left, forced a Nembhard miscue on the ensuing inbounds pass to give Boston another shot.\n\nOut of a Mazzulla timeout, Holiday found Brown in the corner for a three that sent the Garden crowd -- rabid all night -- into hysterics.\n\nHaliburton nearly delivered another highlight-reel 3-pointer as time expired, but it missed the mark, sending the game to overtime tied at 117-117.\n\nDown 123-121 with 1:12 remaining in the extra session, Tatum drove baseline for a tough layup, drawing a foul on McConnell and sinking his and-1 free throw. Holiday promptly forced a turnover, and Tatum buried a three put Boston up four.\n\nHaliburton, Indiana's All-Star point guard, buried his face in his palms as he walked back to the Pacers bench. Indiana now will look to replicate what Miami and Cleveland did in the previous two rounds and beat Boston on its home floor in Game 2.", "source": {"uri": "bostonherald.com", "dataType": "news", As the higher-seeded, heavy favorite team at home, you play with fire when you give away an early game in the series.\n\nIndiana was up by 5 with 1:43 left in regulation in the TD Garden, and they were still up 3 with 10 seconds to go when they botched an inbounds play, giving Boston one more chance to tie the game. The Pacers didn't foul and Jalen Brown didn't miss.\n\nIn overtime, Jayson Tatum took over scoring 10 points, both hitting 3s and getting into the paint and drawing fouls.\n\nBoston came from behind -- but it feels more like an escape -- and got the win, 133-128 in OT.\n\nThe Celtics lead the series 1-0 with Game 2 in Boston on Thursday.\n\nThat is going to feel like an exceedingly long 48 hours for the Pacers.\n\n\"This loss is totally on me,\" Pacers coach Rick Carlisle said. \"With 10 seconds in regulation, we should have just taken the timeout, advance the ball and found a way to get it in and made a free throw or two and ended the game.\"\n\nBoston players sounded like they were exhaling more than celebrating.\n\n\"Would you be?\" Brown said. \"We almost dropped a game on our home floor. We need to come out and be better in Game 2.\"\n\nIt started out pretty. The Celtics race out to 12-0 lead after the opening tip -- including a successful Boston challenge -- and early on the Celtics were getting whatever they wanted against the Pacers defense.\n\nHowever, as the game settled in, Boston was happy to run with the Pacers in a free-flowing, wide-open game -- and that's exactly what the Pacers want. The Celtics were content to move the ball around on the perimeter and shoot a lot of 3s, but that plays into the Pacers' hands. Indiana's pick-and-roll also gave Boston fits all game long -- the Celtics switched but didn't want to put two on the ball and they may have to.\n\nMyles Turner was hot and scored 18 points in the first half, Tyrese Haliburton hit three 3-pointers, Obi Toppin had a spark with 11 off the bench, and the game was tied at 64-64 at the half.\n\nIn the second half, Boston did better in stretches to play north and south, but Indiana was in its groove. At the end of the game, they attacked Al Horford relentlessly, dragging him into every pick-and-roll then isolating against him.\n\nHaliburton finished the game with 25 points and 10 assists, Pascal Siakam had 24 points and 12 rebounds, and Turner had 23 points and 10 boards. Obi Toppin had a strong game off the bench with 15 points. The Pacers had a plan stuck to it.\n\nIndiana did everything it needed to except execute with the lead in the clutch.\n\nBoston did.\n\nTatum finished with 36 points and 12 rebounds, Brown had 26, and Jrue Holiday had a strong game with 28 points and eight assists.\n\nGame 2 will be as much a mental test for the Pacers as a physical one. Can the Pacers bounce back after losing one they should have put in the win column?\n\nIndiana made one thing clear -- this is a series. So we have got to come out and be better,\" he added.\n\nThe Pacers came into the game on the back of a gruelling game seven win against the New York Knicks on Sunday and Boston were the fastest out of the traps.\n\nWith the loud home crowd sensing Indiana were struggling, Al Horford's 26-foot three pointer made it 12-0.\n\nThe Pacers got back into the game and levelled it 64-64 at half-time.\n\nA 13-point run in the third put Boston 87-77 up but again Indiana came back and with less than two minutes to go they led 115-100.\n\nCostly turnovers\n\nIndiana turned the ball over twice in the final 30 seconds of regulation before Brown's crucial three pointer, over the top of Siakam.\n\nWhen Haliburton was unable to get off a last-gasp shot the game went to overtime.\n\nA step back three-pointer from Tatum with 43 left put Boston four points up.\n\nAfter Derrick White's layup extended the advantage to six with 25 seconds left, the game was beyond the Pacers.\n\n\"We were able to make some plays at the end but we have got to be better to be honest, but I'll take the win,\" said Brown.\n\nPacers head coach Rick Carlisle said he was to blame for allowing the Celtics to take the game to overtime.\n\n\"The loss is totally on me,\" he said.\n\n\"With 10 seconds left in regulation, we should have just taken the time out, advanced the ball and found a way to get it in and made a free throw or two and ended the game.\n\n\"But it didn't happen and we made some other mistakes,\" he added, referring to the team's turnover problems.\n\n\"We know we made mistakes and {"uri": "8139651282", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "04:55:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T04:55:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T04:55:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.thepeterboroughexaminer.com/sports/basketball/tatum-scores-36-celtics-edge-pacers-133-128-in-ot-in-game-1-of-east/article_77b53bcc-dd55-5d20-a5b4-4d7115570bc3.html", "title": "Tatum scores 36, Celtics edge Pacers 133-128 in OT in Game 1 of East finals", "body": "BOSTON (AP) -- The Celtics entered the playoffs expecting to get everyone's best shot.\n\nThe East's top seed barely survived a tough one to open the Eastern Conference finals.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nJayson Tatum scored 36 points, including 10 in overtime after Jaylen Brown's tying 3-pointer with 6.1 seconds remaining in regulation, and Boston rallied just in time for a 133-128 victory over the Indiana Pacers on Tuesday night.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nJrue Holiday added a season-high 28 points and Brown finished with 26.\n\n\"Welcome to the NBA playoffs. You've just got to manage your emotions. Anything can happen,\" Brown said of his tying 3. \"It's not over until the final buzzer sounds. ... It's not over until it's over. We found a way to win the game at the very end.\"\n\nIt gave his team a new life and helped it hang on to home-court advantage with Game 2 set for Thursday in Boston.\n\nTyrese Haliburton had 25 points and 10 assists for the Pacers, who knocked down 13 3-pointers and scored 56 points in the paint against a Celtics team still playing without 7-footer Kristaps Porzingis.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nBut Boston dialed up its defence, finishing with 11 steals -- three each by Brown, Tatum and Holiday. The Celtics become the first team in NBA playoff history to have three players record 25 points and three steals in a game.\n\nYou might be interested in Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe Celtics were cold for most of the game from 3-point range, but ended the night 15 of 45 from beyond the arc.\n\n\"We keep talking about protecting home court,\" Celtics forward Al Horford said. \"It's whatever it takes.\"\n\nPascal Siakam added 24 points and 12 rebounds. Myles Turner finished with 23 points and 10 rebounds for the sixth-seeded Pacers, who twice turned it over with a three-point lead in the final 30 seconds of regulation.\n\nBrown made them pay for the second one, hitting a 3 from the corner with Siakam right in his face to tie it at 117.\n\n\"Jrue made a good pass, (Derrick White) set a great screen and the rest is history,\" Brown said.\n\nCeltics coach Joe Mazzulla like the poise Brown showed.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"Jaylen had great balance,\" he said. \"Great pass, great shot.\"\n\nPacers coach Rick Carlisle said the loss was \"totally on me\" for not calling a timeout to advance the ball before their turnover that set up Brown's shot.\n\nAsked about the 21 turnovers Indiana committed, Haliburton said many of them were preventable.\n\n\"I think it's more on us,\" he said. \"I just felt like more of them were probably on us than them forcing turnovers.\"\n\nThe Celtics are now 2-2 when their opponent scores 100 or more points.\n\nHoliday said the Celtics never panicked after falling behind late in regulation\n\n\"I think we always knew that there's always a chance. We've seen crazy stuff happen all the time,\" Holiday said. \"I don't think that we think we lost the game until we actually lost the game and that's part of the reason why we were so resilient.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nIndiana went back ahead 123-121 when Haliburton hit all three free throws after being fouled with 1:46 remaining. Tatum then muscled in a layup and was fouled by T.J. McConnell. He completed the three-point play to put Boston ahead for good.\n\nThe Pacers turned it over again, this time by Haliburton. The ball found its way to Tatum at the top of key. He pumped, sidestepped a defender and sunk a 3 to make it 127-123 with 43 seconds left.\n\nWhite and Siakam traded layups. Holiday was fouled and hit two free throws to give Boston a 131-125 cushion.\n\n\"It's unfortunate we did so many good things in this game that it came down to a couple of mistakes at the end, but it's the NBA playoffs,\" Carlisle said. \"We've got to learn from it and we've got to bounce back.\"\n\n-- -\n\nAP NBA: https://apnews.com/hub/nba", "source": {"uri": "thepeterboroughexaminer.com", The Celtics were able to come out on top with a 133-128 overtime win. Jayson Tatum led the Celtics with 36 points, 12 rebounds, and he was 10-12 from the charity stripe. Jrue Holiday and Jaylen Brown each had over 25 points in the win, as well. As a team, the Celtics were able to shoot 47.5 from the floor, and they took a total of 30 free throws. The Celtics Kristaps Porzingis remains out for this game.\n\nThe Pacers had a very good offensive game in the loss as they put up 128 points. Tyrese Haliburton stole the show for Indiana. He had 25 points and 10 assists, including a couple shots made at the buzzer. Pascal Siakam and Myles Turner each recorded a 20+ point double-double, as well. The Pacers shot just 10 free throws in the loss, but they did shoot over 50 percent from the floor.\n\nThe Pacers win games on the offensive side of the floor, and this series is going to be no different. They di not play great defensively during the regular season, and they are not all the good in the playoffs either. However, Indiana is leading all playoff teams in scoring with 115.2 points per game. In fact, the Pacers lead that category by almost five full points. Indiana needs to continue this type of offensive play if they want to upset the Celtics in this game.\n\nThe Pacers allowed the Celtics to shoot 30 free throws in game one of this series. That is a big reason why they lost the game. Indiana has to stay out of foul trouble. The Pacers are not afraid to foul, but it has gotten them in trouble. If they can keep their hands off, and keep the Celtics away from the free throw line, they will have a chance to win this game.\n\nWhy The Celtics Could Cover The Spread/Win\n\nBoston put up 133 points in the first game of the series, but it was not really a surprise. The Pacers, as mentioned, are not the greatest defensive team. In the regular season, the Pacers allowed the 120.2 points per game, which was the fourth-most in the NBA. In the playoffs, the Pacers are allowing 112.4, so a little better, but still the third-most of all playoff teams. Boston should be able to have the same type of offensive game Thursday night, and win the game.\n\nDefensively, the Celtics allowed 128 points in game one. However, that is an anomaly. Boston is usually much better than that on the defensive side of the floor. In fact, the Celtics have allowed less than 100 points per game in the playoffs this season. That is something that should continue in this game. They need to find a way to contain one of either Siakam or Haliburton, but Boston should not give up another 128 points in this game.\n\nFinal Pacers-Celtics Prediction & Pick\n\nI do think the Celtics win this game. {"uri": "8140518154", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "14:14:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T14:14:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T14:14:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.nbcsports.com/nba/news/five-takeaways-from-celtics-game-1-win-over-pacers", "title": "Five takeaways from Celtics' Game 1 win over Pacers", "body": "It was chaotic and intense, it went to overtime but the Boston Celtics escaped at home with a Game 1 win in the Eastern Conference Finals -- and the Indiana Pacers let a prime chance to steal a game on the road slip through their fingers.\n\nIt's a loss the Pacers will regret - you only get so many chances to win on the road in the playoffs.\n\nHere are the five big takeaways from Game 1 -- that don't involve Jaylen Brown hitting corner 3s.\n\nJaylen Brown hit the big shot that forced overtime. Jayson Tatum led the team in scoring.\n\nJrue Holiday was the best Celtic on the court and they don't win Game 1 without him. Don't take my word for it.\n\n\"Shoutout to Jrue. He's the reason why we won this game...\" Jaylen Brown said. \"That was special from Jrue Holiday.\"\n\nOn offense, he attacked Tyrese Haliburton on his way to a season-high 28 points on 10-of-16 shooting, adding eight assists and seven rebounds. However, his defense on Halibuton, particularly in overtime, was even more critical.\n\n\"[Holiday] is the best defender in the NBA and has been for a long time...\" Tyrese Haliburton said postgame. \"I'll learn from it and I'll be better in Game 2.\"\n\nHoliday is the one guy on the Celtics with a ring and this is exactly why Brad Stevens went and got him right before the season -- on an up-and-down night for most of the Celtics, Holiday was steady. The Celtics aren't up 1-0 in this series without them.\n\nIndiana did not take care of the ball and it cost them -- and not just the obvious turnover inbounding the ball with 10 seconds left, giving Boston and Brown one more chance to tie the game. It was all night long.\n\nIndiana turned the ball over 22 times, or 19.6% of their possessions -- in almost one-in-five trips down the court, the Pacers coughed up the ball (or had a 24 second violation, or an offensive foul).\n\nThose 22 turnovers became 32 Boston points in a game that went to overtime.\n\nIf the Pacers are going to keep the rest of this series close and have a chance to come back, they have to take care of the ball.\n\nFor much of the night -- particularly in the first half, but for stretches in the second as well -- the Celtics were happy to get sucked into the Pacers up-tempo, free-flowing game. It almost cost them the win.\n\nIndiana is not a great defensive team but they play relentlessly fast and it's easy for other teams to get sucked into that pace -- they just can't do it as well as Indiana.\n\nBoston raced out to a 12-0 lead to open the game but got sucked into Indiana's style of play, was happy to move the ball around the perimeter rather than get inside, and by halftime, it was 64-64. The Celtics did a better but inconsistent job in the second half slowing the game down and playing north/south with Tatum, Brown and Holiday driving into the paint.\n\nBoston has to play that way, if it plays Indiana's game it will lose.\n\nRick Carlisle is in the \"don't foul late when up 3\" camp -- his teams don't do it.\n\nThey didn't do it after the turnover near the end of regulation. Indiana was still up 3 with 8.5 seconds left, the Pacers didn't play to foul and Brown hit the 3-pointer to force overtime. LeBron James commented from home.\n\nLeBron and J.J. Redick discussed this on their \"Mind the Game\" podcast. It's situational, but if time and the situation allow it, LeBron is in the \"foul and give up two free throws\" camp.\n\nCould Pascal Siakam have fouled Brown? Maybe not in this case because he was so intent on fighting through Derrick White's screen below the arc (despite the Pacers being up 3) that he was late to close out and Brown got a clean look. The Pacers didn't defend that well, but they didn't appear to be looking to foul -- Carlisle's teams generally do not foul anyway. It cost them in this case.\n\nAt the end of the game, the Pacers relentlessly targeted Al Horford, even if it meant an Andrew Nembhard isolation (not exactly Indiana's best play). It worked.\n\nIt was clear throughout the game, not just at the end, how much Kristaps Porzingis, his defense, his 3-point shooting, and his mobility would matter in this series.\n\nPorzingis is targeting a Game 4 return, ESPN's Adrian Wojnarowski reported pregame. What Porzignis will the Celtics get? How is\n\nhe moving coming off a calf strain? Is he on a minute's limit? How long will it take him to shake off the rust.\n\nBoston may not get the 100% of Porzingis when he returns, but it needs whatever he can give in this series.", "source": {"uri": "nbcsports.com", AFP PHOTO\n\nTatum top scored for Boston with 36 points, 10 of them in overtime, collecting 12 rebounds and four assists with Brown putting up 26 and Jrue Holiday, 28.\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\nIndiana, who fought back from large deficits several times in the game, were led by Tyrese Haliburton's 25 points, 10 assists and three rebounds with Pascal Siakam making 24 points, seven assists and 12 rebounds.\n\nBrown was far from happy with the performance from Boston, who had almost a week off after their 4-1 series win over Cleveland.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"A lot of ups and downs, I don't think we played our best,\" said three-time All Star Brown.\n\n\"We almost dropped the game on our own floor. So we have got to come out and be better,\" he added.\n\nThe Pacers came into the game on the back of a grueling Game 7 win against the New York Knicks on Sunday and Boston were the fastest out of the traps.\n\nWith the loud home crowd sensing Indiana were struggling, Al Horford's 26-foot three-pointer made it 12-0.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe Pacers got back into the game and leveled it 64-64 at half-time.\n\nA 13-point run in the third put Boston 87-77 up but again Indiana came back and with less than two minutes to go they led 115-100.\n\nIndiana turned the ball over twice in the final 30 seconds of regulation before Brown's crucial three-pointer, over the top of Siakam.\n\nWhen Haliburton was unable to get off a last-gasp shot, the game went to overtime.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nA step back three-pointer from Tatum with 43 left put Boston four points up.\n\nAfter Derrick White's layup extended the advantage to six with 25 seconds left, the game was beyond the Pacers.\n\n\"We were able to make some plays at the end but we have got to be better to be honest, but I'll take the win,\" said Brown.\n\nPacers head coach Rick Carlisle said he was to blame for allowing the Celtics to take the game to overtime.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"The loss is totally on me,\" he said.\n\n\"With 10 seconds left in regulation, we should have just taken the time out, advanced the ball and found a way to get it in and made a free throw or two and ended the game.\n\n\"But it didn't happen, and we made some other mistakes,\" he added, referring to the team's turnover problems.\n\n\"We know we made mistakes and that is an area we have got to clean up,\" said Carlisle.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"We have been a tough-minded, resilient team for almost the entire second half of the year but we have {"uri": "8139696546", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "05:34:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T05:34:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T05:34:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/40193041/2024-nba-playoffs-biggest-takeaways-chaotic-game-1-boston-indiana", "title": "Biggest takeaways from a chaotic Game 1 between Boston and Indiana", "body": "Game 1 of the Eastern Conference finals between the Boston Celtics and Indiana Pacers had a little bit of everything:\n\nThere was a historic level of offense. The two teams combined for 261, the highest-scoring game so far this postseason and the most combined points in a conference finals game since 1987.\n\nThere were critical turnovers. The Pacers gave it away 22 times, their second most this season, but it didn't stop the heavy underdog from overcoming multiple double-digit deficits, including a 12-0 run by the Celtics to open the game.\n\nThere were momentum-shifting shots from long range. Pacers All-Star guard Tyrese Haliburton hit two of them, one from 35 feet just before halftime and another that banked off the backboard twice before beating the third-quarter buzzer.\n\nIt all led to the frantic final moments of regulation that featured multiple miscues by the Pacers, culminating in Celtics wing Jaylen Brown burying a contested corner 3-pointer that forced overtime and helped Boston pull off a 133-128 miracle win.\n\nNow that we're up to speed on one of the wildest games of the 2024 postseason, our NBA insiders are breaking down the biggest moments of Game 1, what could be next in Thursday's Game 2 (8 p.m. ET on ESPN) and how to describe that wild late sequence inside Boston's TD Garden.\n\nTim Bontemps: The Celtics escaped. Boston was seconds away from falling to 15-15 at home over the last three postseasons -- an inexplicable statistic for a team that lost just four games inside TD Garden this season -- and drop another game to a massive playoff underdog. And yet, Boston found a way to survive behind Jaylen Brown's game-tying 3 - and the poise and presence of guard Jrue Holiday. In many ways, this was the first true playoff game Boston has played in this postseason, and Holiday delivered everything the Celtics hoped he would when they acquired him on the eve of training camp back in September.\n\nJamal Collier: The Pacers showed they can hang with the Celtics. A few minutes into the game after Boston raced out to a 12-0 lead in the first quarter, it looked like this was headed for a blowout. But Indiana responded as it has all season, overcoming two separate double-digit deficits in the game to take the lead both times. The Pacers showed they have a blueprint to make this a competitive series against the top-seeded Celtics, especially if Haliburton can continue shooting this well. He hit six 3-pointers in Game 1, including back-to-back buzzer beaters to end the second and third quarters.\n\nChris Herring: Playoffs or not, this is going to be a wildly uptempo series -- even in the closing moments, which can and should make for more chaos than we're used to.\n\nMore importantly, we're already seeing that Indiana is likely going to lose the free-throw battle by a considerable margin each game. During the regular season, on a per-shot-attempt basis, the Pacers sent their opponents to the line at the highest rate in the league, while the Celtics sent their opponents to the stripe at the NBA's lowest rate. That dichotomy played out in Game 1. Boston got 30 free throws to Indiana's 10, and Jayson Tatum had 12 attempts by himself.\n\nBontemps: Boston desperately needs to improve its defense inside the 3-point line. Indiana shot 62.5% from 2-point range in Game 1 -- 66.1% at the end of regulation -- as the Celtics felt the loss of 7-foot-3 Kristaps Porzingis' paint protection. Brown said postgame that Boston had to adjust to Indiana's level of pace as the game wore on despite the Pacers needing to overcome a grueling seven-game series against the New York Knicks just two days ago.\n\nCollier: The Pacers have to take care of the ball. It's obvious and hasn't been an issue for the Indy for most of this season (they averaged the second fewest turnovers per game among playoff teams entering Game 1), but the Pacers got careless with the ball when it mattered most at the end of Game 1. Indiana center Myles Turner said it was the first time during this playoff run he thought the team showed its age with such uncharacteristic mistakes. Whatever the cause may be, the Pacers have to hold onto the ball in Game 2 and not allow Boston to get anywhere close to the 32 points off turnovers they recorded in the first game.\n\nHerring: After how the Pacers pulled ahead late, I wouldn't be surprised if the Celtics look for a way to tighten things up defensively in clutch time, whether it's through different switch patterns or simply playing up higher and risking leaving the rim area a bit more vulnerable; especially considering how rarely Indiana got to the free throw line.\n\nSpecifically, the Pacers carved up 37-year-old big man Al Horford from the midrange in the fourth quarter and in overtime, connecting on 6-of-9 attempts when Horford was the primary defender during that stretch. That shouldn't come as a surprise; the Pacers were the league's most efficient midrange shooting team during the regular season.\n\nBontemps: Chaotic. There were wild passes. Inexplicable turnovers. Wide open shots missing badly. It was everything that comes with the crucible of the final moments of a nip-and-tuck playoff game. Both Jaylen Brown and Jrue Holiday essentially said the same thing postgame: Boston never believed the game was over until it actually was. The Celtics may have been the only ones inside TD Garden to believe that, but they wound up being right.\n\nCollier: Unpredictable. That game went from \"close but Boston doesn't really look threatened here\" to \"wait, the Pacers are going to steal this game\" to \"Oh my, how did the Pacers blow this?\" Losing a playoff game after inbounding the ball up three points with 10 seconds remaining put the Pacers in a category with historically unlikely losers; they were the first team to drop a playoff game in such fashion since 1997-98.\n\nHerring: Ugly. Indiana had so many \"we've never been here\" mistakes. Haliburton lost the ball multiple times, and waited too long to get a shot off as time expired in regulation. The Pacers forced a terrible inbounds pass late, even though they had a timeout to spare. And none of this even touches on the fact that Haliburton looked as if he was trying to commit a late intentional foul in transition, which would have given Boston two critical free throws.\n\nIn all, Indy had more than twice as many turnovers (five) as it had field goals (two) in the final 5:30 of regulation and overtime. Boston made plenty of miscues, too. But as the favorite and the club with home court advantage, the Celtics can afford that. The Pacers can't.", "source": {"uri": "espn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ESPN.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA_Conference_Finals", "type": "wiki", {"uri": "2024-05-364148304", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "06:02:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T06:02:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T04:17:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/celtics-grind-to-overtime-pacers-win-in-east-finals-opener/article_6c053107-45c3-5c12-8e0c-575f48f86a5a.html", "title": "Celtics grind to overtime Pacers win in East finals opener", "body": "Jayson Tatum of the Boston Celtics celebrates the overtime win with Derrick White\n\nThe Boston Celtics needed a late rally to force overtime against the Indiana Pacers before emerging with a 133-128 win in game one of the Eastern Conference Finals on Tuesday.\n\nBoston's Jaylen Brown sank a three-pointer from the corner with 6.1 seconds remaining to tie the scores at 117-117 and take it to overtime.\n\nThen Jayson Tatum made a crucial late three-pointer to push the Celtics to victory and a 1-0 lead in the best-of-seven series.\n\nTatum top scored for Boston with 36 points, 10 of them in overtime, collecting 12 rebounds and four assists with Brown putting up 26 and Jrue Holiday 28.\n\nIndiana, who fought back from large deficits several times in the game, were led by Tyrese Haliburton's 25 points, 10 assists and three rebounds with Pascal Siakam making 24 points, seven assists and 12 rebounds.\n\nBrown was far from happy with the performance from Boston, who had almost a week off after their 4-1 series win over Cleveland.\n\n\"A lot of ups and downs, I don't think we played our best,\" said three-time All Star Brown.\n\n\"We almost dropped the game on our own floor. So we have got to come out and be better,\" he added.\n\nThe Pacers came into the game on the back of a gruelling game seven win against the New York Knicks on Sunday and Boston were the fastest out of the traps.\n\nWith the loud home crowd sensing Indiana were struggling, Al Horford's 26-foot three pointer made it 12-0.\n\nThe Pacers got back into the game and levelled it 64-64 at half-time.\n\nA 13-point run in the third put Boston 87-77 up but again Indiana came back and with less than two minutes to go they led 115-100.\n\n- Costly turnovers -\n\nIndiana turned the ball over twice in the final 30 seconds of regulation before Brown's crucial three pointer, over the top of Siakam.\n\nWhen Haliburton was unable to get off a last-gasp shot the game went to overtime.\n\nA step back three-pointer from Tatum with 43 left put Boston four points up.\n\nAfter Derrick White's layup extended the advantage to six with 25 seconds left, the game was beyond the Pacers.\n\n\"We were able to make some plays at the end but we have got to be better to be honest, but I'll take the win,\" said Brown.\n\nPacers head coach Rick Carlisle said he was to blame for allowing the Celtics to take the game to overtime.\n\n\"The loss is totally on me,\" he said.\n\n\"With 10 seconds left in regulation, we should have just taken the time out, advanced the ball and found a way to get it in and made a free throw or two and ended the game.\n\n\"But it didn't happen and we made some other mistakes,\" he added, referring to the team's turnover problems.\n\n\"We know we made mistakes and that is an area we have got to clean up,\" said Carlisle.\n\n\"We have been a tough-minded, resilient team for almost the entire second half of the year but we have to continue with that and come back here on Thursday night.\"\n\nsev/dh\n\nMore from this section\n\nMontana's attorney general said he recruited token primary opponent to increase campaign fundraising New sales workshop 'Extreme
