Boston led by as many as 13 in the second half and it looked like they were going to cruise to a win. However, the Indiana Pacers wouldn't go away. The Pacers climbed back into the game, and they took a five-point lead with under two minutes to go. They also led by three with under 10 seconds left and they had the ball. They ended up committing a turnover, and then Jaylen Brown drilled a three to send the game to over time.\n\nJaylen Brown was the hero for the Celtics in game one after his heroic shot to send the game to overtime. It looked like Boston was dead in the water, but Brown sparked some life back into his team, and they found a way to get the win in OT.\n\nAfter the Pacers turned the ball over and gave it back to the Celtics with under 10 seconds left, Boston had a chance to draw up a play. It worked to perfection, and Brown knew that he was going to be open for the three.\n\n\"We drew up a play, and it was perfectly executed, I told Jrue [Holiday] I was going to be open in the corner, and I was,\" Brown said after the game during a post-game interview.\n\nJaylen Brown was right, he had an opening in the corner, and he took it. The Celtics are now up 1-0 in the series.\n\nThe Pacers let game one slip away\n\nIf you're the Celtics, you're feeling great right now after surviving game one and taking a 1-0 lead in the series. Boston is the heavy favorite to win the series, and they are now one step closer to achieving their goal after Jaylen Brown helped them get the win.\n\nAs for the Pacers, that one hurts bad. Indiana had a chance to go on the road and completely change the perception of this series. If they can go up 1-0 in this series, they put a ton of pressure on the Celtics. As the favorite to win it all, there is already a lot of pressure on Boston. The Pacers let a golden opportunity slip right through their fingertips in game one.\n\nNow, the Pacers have to regroup as game two will be on Thursday. The game will begin at 8:00 ET, and it will be airing on ESPN. {"uri": "2024-05-364038068", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "03:29:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T03:29:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T03:24:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.philstar.com/sports/2024/05/22/2357063/celtics-edge-pacers-ot-draw-first-blood-nba-east-finals", "title": "Celtics edge Pacers in OT to draw first blood in NBA East finals", "body": "MANILA, Philippines - The Boston Celtics fended off the gritty Indiana Pacers to take Game 1 of the NBA Eastern Conference Finals in overtime, 133-128, at the TD Garden Wednesday (Manila time).\n\nThe Celtics blew a 13-point lead in the second half but regained their composure late in the fourth quarter and overtime to go up 1-0.\n\nJayson Tatum led Boston with 36 points, 12 rebounds, four assists and three steals. He scored 10 points in overtime to power the league's top regular season team to the victory.\n\nWith Indiana ahead by just two, 123-121, in overtime following three free throws by Tyrese Haliburton, Tatum took over.\n\nThe sweet-shooting forward first sank an and-one play to help the Celtics go up by one, 124-123.\n\nAfter a Haliburton turnover on the other end, Boston once again went to Tatum, who faked a shot and side-stepped his way to a clean look from way beyond for the 127-123 cushion.\n\nAfter another turnover by Indiana, a cutting layup by Derrick White pushed the advantage to six, 129-123.\n\nA mini 5-2 run by the Pacers kept them in the game, 131-128, but Tatum iced the game with a pair of free throws with 8.6 seconds remaining.\n\nWith the game going down the wire, 114-115, with less than a minute to go in regulation with a pair of free throws by Jaylen Brown, Andrew Nembhard sank a big step-back midrange jumper over the outstretched arms of Al Horford.\n\nTatum missed a wide-open triple that would have tied the game, but the Pacers committed a big turnover on the other end to give Boston another opportunity.\n\nWhite and Tatum then missed their chances as Indiana took the possession.\n\nHowever, another turnover on the inbound pass gave the Celtics a shot at to tie the game, with Brown capitalizing by sinking a corner trey with Siakam right on his jersey to tie the game up at 117 with 5.7 seconds left.\n\nIn the next play, Tatum locked down Haliburton to bring the game to overtime, setting up the cardiac finish.\n\n\"Indiana, they play so fast. They put pressure on you. We gotta be better going forward but we give credit to Indiana, they play so fast, we have to be able to keep up,\" Brown said after the game.\n\n\"We just made some momentum plays. JT finally woke up, made some baskets... We gotta be better to be honest, but we'll take the win tonight.\"\n\nJrue Holiday backstopped the Celtics' top performer with 28 points, eight assists, seven rebounds and three steals, while Brown had 26.\n\nSeven Pacers finished in double digits, led by Haliburton with 25 points, 10 assists and three rebounds.\n\nPascal Siakam provided 24 markers, 12 boards and seven dimes. Myles Turner aided Indiana with 23 points and 10 rebounds.\n\nGame 2 is on Friday morning (Manila time) at the same venue.", "source": {"uri": "philstar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": Tatum helped seal the game with a three-pointer to give the Celtics a 1-0 series lead.\n\nTatum led Boston with 36 points, while Jrue Holiday added 28. Tyrese Haliburton paced Indiana with 25 points with Pascal Siakam adding 24 and Myles Turner 23.\n\nThe Celtics raced out to 12-0 lead, forcing Pacers head coach Rick Carlisle to call a time out. Indiana responded with 11 points from Obi Toppin to cut the deficit to just three after the first quarter.\n\nThe Pacers kept pace with Boston in the second behind strong play from Turner, who scored 18 points in the first half. Indiana tied the game at 57 on an Aaron Nesmith dunk. Haliburton made a 35-foot three-pointer two seconds before halftime to tie the game at 64.\n\nThe Pacers had 22 assists in the first half.\n\nHaliburton started the second half with a lay-up and three-pointer to put Indiana up five. The Pacers led 75-74 when the Celtics went on a 13-0 run. A Holiday three-pointer put Boston up by 13. Indiana responded with its own run. Haliburton banked in a three as time expired in the third to trim the deficit to just a point entering the final quarter.\n\nThe fourth quarter was back-and-forth before he Pacers took a four-point lead on a Siakam jumper and dunk. Andrew Nembhard put Indiana up three to set-up Brown's clutch three.\n\nGame 2 is set for Tuesday night at 8:00 p.m. at the TD Garden in Boston.", "source": {"uri": "fox59.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8140718398", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "16:27:20", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T16:27:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T16:26:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.unionleader.com/sports/celtics/commentary-who-says-the-celtics-can-t-pull-out-a-close-playoff-game/article_35eeabfc-1852-11ef-b40a-f31b7b91aa3a.html", "title": "Commentary: Who says the Celtics can't pull out a close playoff game?", "body": "BOSTON -- If the Celtics go on to claim Banner 18, their Game 1 overtime win over the Indiana Pacers in the Eastern Conference finals might prove to be the most pivotal during the run.\n\nThe knock on the Green Team during the season, as well as past playoff appearances, was their lack of finish, their inability to win the close games.\n\nThey needed to get over that hurdle to assuage the fears of their doubters, and perhaps fears of their own.\n\nAnd while Tuesday night's 133-128 overtime win was both infuriating and exhilarating, the Celtics ultimately showed their mettle and resolve when it counted.\n\nYes, they wilted, blowing a 13-point lead with four minutes to play in the third quarter. They sure seemed to be headed down a familiar path. But just when it looked like they were destined to keep the choke collar, they rose up. They grew strong in those pivotal, got-to-have it moments.\n\nThey took advantage of the countless gaffes made by the Pacers, making them pay for their miscues, but none greater than the one with a few ticks remaining in regulation.\n\nDown three with the clock running down from 10 seconds after the Pacers' umpteenth turnover, Celtics forward Jaylen Brown calmly hit a corner bomb to tie the game and send it to overtime.\n\nBrown, who had a disastrous Game 7 performance in the Eastern finals last season, said he basically willed the shot in.\n\n\"I was just telling myself the whole time, if you get it, it's going up and it's going in,\" Brown said. \"I was able to make a big-time play.\"\n\nHe sure did with Pascal Siakam in his face as he launched his off-balance prayer to tie the game.\n\nThen it was Jayson Tatum's turn to be the hero. He scored 10 of his 36 points in overtime, including a 3-pointer that put the nail in the Pacers' coffin with 42.8 seconds to go.\n\nTatum, who was having a rough shooting night (12-of-26, 2-of-8 from three), finally dialed it up during crunch time.\n\nBut Tatum and Brown weren't alone.\n\nJrue Holiday, who has largely sacrificed his scoring this season, also rose down the stretch and overtime with 20 of his 28 points coming after halftime.\n\nBottom line: The Celtics needed to win a game like this. If they do advance to the NBA Finals, they needed to know they can deliver in key spots, in the big games.\n\nAlthough, listening to the players after the game, they never doubted they were capable.\n\n\"I think we always knew we could (win),\" said Holiday. \"Close games, I don't think, have ever bothered us. I think we've always stayed poised no matter if it's a win or a loss. We'd always give ourselves a chance again today. But, down 3, with seconds left, making a big shot and making big plays after that, we knew we had it in us.\"\n\nOf course, the Pacers were a willing accomplice. They helped the Celtics, giving them life, or, as Tatum put it, \"a second chance\" with all of their bumbling. Their whopping 21 turnovers led to 32 Celtics points.\n\nAt different points during the fourth quarter when they seemed to have the game in hand, the Pacers just gave the Celtics more chances time and again. Ditto overtime.\n\nAndrew Nembhard's wayward inbound pass with 10 seconds to play set up Brown for the tying score. Then why didn't the Pacers foul Brown, who is not the best free throw shooter in the world, before allowing him to take that three? It's almost an automatic to foul if a team is up by three with little time left on the clock.\n\nPacers had coach Rick Carlisle fell on the sword for his team's meltdown, saying he should have called a timeout to advance the ball, and draw up a better inbounds play.\n\nSo maybe the Celtics were lucky. Maybe the Pacers gift-wrapped the win. By the same token, Boston took advantage of its good fortune.\n\n\"I felt like we hit, they responded. They hit, we responded. It was just a lot of back-and-forth,\" Boston's Al Horford said after the Game 1 win. \"I think, despite all that, our group just stayed the course. We continued to work. We continued to try to play the right way. Eventually, we needed some sort of break and we got it there. I'm glad we were able to close it out in overtime.\"\n\nAdded Holiday: \"I think we always knew there was a chance. We've seen crazy stuff happen all the time ... Anything can happen. We're just the type of team that's going to keep fighting, no matter how long, no matter what it takes.\"\n\nThe Celtics were able to snatch a victory from defeat. In many cases, it's been the other way around. They've grabbed defeat, out of sure wins.\n\n\"It's not over til it's over,\" Brown said, spouting a familiar refrain, \"and we found a way to win this game at the very end.\"\n\nFinding a way in Game 1, could very well pay bigger dividends when they're forced to muster similar resolve down the road.", "source": {"uri": "unionleader.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "UnionLeader.com"}, "authors": {"uri": "2024-05-364030723", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "03:15:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T03:15:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T03:12:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://eu.indystar.com/story/sports/nba/pacers/2024/05/21/jaylen-browns-3-gives-celtics-life-as-they-beat-pacers-in-overtime/73788605007/", "title": "Pacers don't foul, Jaylen Brown's 3 forces OT and Celtics beat Pacers in extra period", "body": "BOSTON -- The Pacers had the Celtics on the ropes, but a stunning 3-pointer by Jaylen Brown with 5.7 seconds left in regulation forced overtime and Boston got clutch buckets in overtime to win Game 1 of the Eastern Conference finals 133-126 at TD Garden.\n\nThe Celtics take a 1-0 series lead into Thursday's Game 2.\n\nHere are four observations.\n\nCeltics stars, Pacers turnovers make difference in final moments and OT\n\nThe Pacers committed 21 turnovers on Tuesday night including several in the final moments and overtime that game the Celtics life.\n\nThe Pacers led by three points with 8.5 seconds left with a chance to inbound, draw a foul and put the game away, but guard Aaron Nembhard's inbound pass went off of Pascal Siakam and out of bounds to go back to the Celtics. The Pacers didn't foul and Celtics forward Jaylen Brown drilled a 3-pointer in the corner with 5.7 seconds to go to tie the game. Pacers All-Star point guard Tyrese Haliburton got in several tied-up positions on the final possession and missed a heave at the buzzer to send the game into overtime.\n\nCeltics All-Star forward Jayson Tatum scored 10 points in overtime including a critical three-point play and 3-pointer. He finished with 36 points on 12 of 26 shooting. Brown had 26 points and guard Jrue Holiday had 28 as the Celtics veterans stepped it up in critical moments.\n\nMyles Turner took advantage of his matchups\n\nWith Kristaps Porzingis out for at least the first two games of this series with a calf strain, there was an obvious imperative for Pacers center Myles Turner to take advantage of his matchups and he very much did.\n\nThe Celtics used 37-year-old Al Horford and gangly 7-2, 240-pounder Luke Kornet at center. Turner went after both, but Kornet especially. In the first half, Turner scored 18 points on 7 of 10 shooting, knocking down a pair of 3-pointers on three attempts and also throwing down a few vicious dunks. He also added four rebounds and dished out four assists as well. He found it harder to take advantage of those matchups in the second half but finished with 23 points on 9 of 13 shooting, grabbing 10 rebounds.\n\nTyrese Haliburton keeps it up\n\nTyrese Haliburton found a rhythm in Game 6 against the Knicks and kept it going against the Celtics, showing aggression off the bounce and accuracy from deep.\n\nHaliburton had to deal with not one but two All-NBA defenders in Celtics guards Jrue Holiday and Derrick White, who were both named to the second team earlier on Tuesday, but ball screens by Turner gave Haliburton opportunities to go down hill and space to step back. He focused on getting the ball to Turner and Obi Toppin at first, but then took advantage of his opportunities as he saw them.\n\nHaliburton scored 11 points in the first half on 4 of 7 shooting including 3 of 5 from 3, hitting a deep 3-pointer just before the half to tie the game. He finished with 25 points on 8 of 18 shooting including 6 of 14 3-pointers to go with 10 assists, but he did have struggles late in the game with turnovers.\n\nPascal Siakam goes off in the second half\n\nThe Pacers started finding Pascal Siakam for mid-range jumpers in the second half and suddenly he couldn't stop making them.\n\nThe All-Star forward scored 16 of his 24 points in the second half, shooting 8 of 14 after the break and 12 of 23 for the game. {"uri": "2024-05-364509018", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "11:22:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T11:22:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T08:57:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.aol.com/loss-totally-indiana-pacers-head-085732856.html", "title": "'Loss is totally on me': Indiana Pacers head coach takes blame for Game 1 loss to Boston Celtics in Eastern Conference Finals", "body": "'Loss is totally on me': Indiana Pacers head coach takes blame for Game 1 loss to Boston Celtics in Eastern Conference FinalsBen Church, CNNMay 22, 2024 at 10:57 AM\n\nIndiana Pacers head coach Rick Carlisle said the 133-128 overtime loss to the Boston Celtics in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference Finals on Tuesday was \"totally on me\" after his team snatched defeat from the jaws of victory.\n\nThe Pacers had a three-point cushion and the ball with just 10 seconds left of regulation time, but Andrew Nembhard's inbound pass to Pascal Siakam ended up in Indiana turning the ball over.\n\nThe costly mistake was punished by Jaylen Brown who leveled the scores at 117-117 with a three-pointer from the corner. The Celtics then got the better of overtime to take a series lead, leaving Carlisle to rue the missed opportunity.\n\n\"I love the way our guys fought in this game. This loss is totally on me. With 10 seconds of regulation, we should have just taken the timeout, advanced the ball and found a way to get it in,\" Carlisle admitted to reporters after the game at Boston's TD Garden.\n\n\"We made some other mistakes, but our guys just need to concentrate on fighting the way they fought in this game, from start to finish.\"\n\nDespite Carlisle taking responsibility for the chaotic end to regulation time, it was an error strewn night from the Pacers, who tallied 22 turnovers which led to 32 points for Boston, according to ESPN.\n\nCarlisle, though, wanted to focus on the positives of which there were some. Boston, for example, had twice led by double digits in the game but Indiana came back on both occasions to take the lead.\n\nThe Pacers head coach was confident his team would recover in time for Game 2 on Thursday.\n\n\"We did a lot of good things that we need to continue to do and we've been a tough minded, resilient team for almost the entire second half of the year and we have to continue that,\" he added.\n\nFor the Celtics, it was a morale boosting start to the series, with Brown and Jayson Tatum leading the charge.\n\nTatum finished on a game-high 36 points, coming up clutch in overtime after Brown had saved the day.\n\n\"Welcome to the NBA Playoffs,\" Brown told reporters. \"You've just got to manage your emotions of the game. Anything can happen. The game is not over until the final buzzer sounds.\"\n\nThe Celtics were also boosted by a career-best performance from Jrue Holiday who totalled 28 points, seven rebounds, eight assists, and three steals.\n\n\"We've seen crazy stuff happen all the time,\" Holiday told reporters.\n\n\"I don't think that we think we've lost a game until we've actually lost a game. That's part of the reason why we were so resilient toward the end of the game; anything can happen.\"\n\nFor more CNN news and newsletters create an account at CNN.com", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", {"uri": "8140581742", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "14:56:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T14:56:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T14:55:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/jaylen-brown-explains-why-he-wasnt-happy-after-celtics-game-1-win-over-pacers/", "title": "Jaylen Brown Explains Why He Wasn't Happy After Celtics' Game 1 Win", "body": "Brown speaks postgame about his frustration over his team's Game 1 victory.\n\nHighlights The Celtics barely won Game 1 thanks to a number of big plays down the stretch. Jaylen Brown was unsatisfied with the win due to the team's performance. The Pacers outplayed the Celtics in various statistical categories.\n\nThe Boston Celtics, having defeated the Indiana Pacers 128-133 in overtime of Game 1, didn't have as smooth a game one as they might have expected. Despite the win and a number of big plays by Boston towards the end, this game felt very much up for grabs almost until the final buzzer sounded.\n\nCeltics star guard Jaylen Brown, after hitting arguably the biggest shot of his career, stayed on the court for a post-game interview in which he was asked about managing emotions in these kinds of games. Brown responded:\n\n\"A lot of ups and downs, [I] don't think we played out best. But the game is fast, you don't have no time to make excuses, you have to keep going and that's what we did tonight... we found a way to win in the end.\"\n\nAs the post-game interviews continued, Brown's frustration was apparent through his answers. When asked about why he didn't seem happy with the win, Brown responded:\n\n\"Would you be? We almost dropped a game on our home floor. We need to come out and be better in Game 2.\"\n\nBrown, although not pleased with the way they won, finished the night with 26 points, seven rebounds, five assists, three steals and a block while shooting 50.0 percent from the field.\n\nDespite the Celtics Win, Pacers Played Extremely Well Besides points scored, Indiana outplayed Boston in a number of different areas\n\nWhen comparing the teams' stats for the game, it's apparent why Brown wasn't pleased with the win. Besides scoring more points, the Pacers grabbed more rebounds, dished more assists and shot better all around than the Celtics.\n\nGame 1 Team Comparison\n\nTeam\n\nPTS\n\nREB\n\nAST\n\nFG%\n\n3P%\n\nPacers\n\n128\n\n44\n\n38\n\n53.5\n\n37.1\n\nCeltics\n\n133\n\n43\n\n30\n\n47.5\n\n33.3\n\nThe Pacers also spread their scoring over their roster, while the majority of the Celtics' points were concentrated to a few players. While only five Celtics scored in double digits, all but one of the Pacers (Ben Sheppard) scored double digits, while three players (Tyrese Haliburton, Pascal Siakam and Myles Turner) scored more than 20.\n\nOne area where Boston did outperform Indiana, though, was in hustle points. Although only edging out the Pacers slightly in these areas, it proved to make enough of a difference to grab the win.\n\nGame 1 Hustle Point Comparison\n\nTeam\n\nPTS in the Paint\n\n2nd Chance PTS\n\nFastbreak PTS\n\nPacers\n\n56\n\n15\n\n14\n\nCeltics\n\n58\n\n19\n\n16\n\nGoing into Game 2, the Celtics will no doubt enter the game with an increased focus on playing tightly and allowing as little room for error as possible. Seemingly an easy task when looking at their home and away splits, but made more interesting by the fact that Boston has yet to win a Game 2 in this postseason (both of which were in So we have got to come out and be better,\" he added.\n\nThe Pacers came into the game on the back of a gruelling game seven win against the New York Knicks on Sunday and Boston were the fastest out of the traps.\n\nWith the loud home crowd sensing Indiana were struggling, Al Horford's 26-foot three pointer made it 12-0.\n\nThe Pacers got back into the game and levelled it 64-64 at half-time.\n\nA 13-point run in the third put Boston 87-77 up but again Indiana came back and with less than two minutes to go they led 115-100.\n\nIndiana turned the ball over twice in the final 30 seconds of regulation before Brown's crucial three pointer, over the top of Siakam.\n\nWhen Haliburton was unable to get off a last-gasp shot the game went to overtime.\n\nA step back three-pointer from Tatum with 43 left put Boston four points up.\n\nAfter Derrick White's layup extended the advantage to six with 25 seconds left, the game was beyond the Pacers.\n\n\"We were able to make some plays at the end but we have got to be better to be honest, but I'll take the win,\" said Brown.\n\nPacers head coach Rick Carlisle said he was to blame for allowing the Celtics to take the game to overtime.\n\n\"The loss is totally on me,\" he said.\n\n\"With 10 seconds left in regulation, we should have just taken the time out, advanced the ball and found a way to get it in and made a free throw or two and ended the game.\n\n\"But it didn't happen and we made some other mistakes,\" he added, referring to the team's turnover problems.\n\n\"We know we made mistakes and that is an area we have got to clean up,\" said Carlisle.\n\n\"We have been a tough-minded, resilient team for almost the entire second half of the year but we have to continue with that and come back here on Thursday and Publishers", "wgt": 19}, {"uri": "dmoz/Games/Resources", "label": "dmoz/Games/Resources", "wgt": 18}, {"uri": "news/Sports", "label": "news/Sports", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://english.ahram.org.eg/Media/News/2024/5/22/41_2024-638519700029079106-907.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9588270", "eventUri": "eng-9588270", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.2549019607843137, "wgt": 181, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8140450340", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "13:32:30", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T13:32:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T13:31:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5511572/2024/05/22/celtics-beat-pacers-game-1-nba-playoffs/", "title": "Celtics survive their first real playoff test in Pacers: 'That s--- was chaos'", "body": "BOSTON -- Jaylen Brown walked along the TD Garden baseline during a stoppage in play late in overtime Tuesday night. Raising his arms into the air, he looked to different sections of the arena and called for more and more cheers from the adoring crowd. He deserved all the love after knocking home a game-tying 3-pointer in the final seconds of regulation and coming up with a crucial steal late in the extra period.\n\nAs Brown demanded more noise, the Boston Celtics were nearing the end of a 133-128 Game 1 victory. After two smooth rounds nearly entirely devoid of drama, they were escaping a wild, fortunate and breathtaking ending.\n\n\"Welcome to the NBA playoffs,\" Brown said.\n\nAt long last, a Celtics playoff game felt like one. To take a 1-0 lead in the Eastern Conference finals, the Celtics needed to persevere through mistakes. They needed to endure pressure. They needed to summon clutch shots and game-saving stops and, sure, several instances of luck, especially late in regulation when Indiana coughed up a turnover while trying to protect a three-point lead. The Pacers' failure to inbound the ball successfully gave possession back to the Celtics with a chance to tie. Brown seized the opportunity with a triple from the corner after Pascal Siakam, with orders to intentionally foul and send Boston to the line, apparently decided hacking Brown before his shot attempt would be too risky. Rick Carlisle defended Siakam's choice, though not his own call to forego a timeout before Indiana's disastrous inbound pass.\n\nThe Celtics needed all of that, a gritty stop on the final possession of regulation and a string of timely plays in overtime. Jayson Tatum, who went quiet for much of the second half, delivered 10 points in overtime to save himself from a few days of criticism. If the Celtics had lost, he said he would have been sick after a bad turnover in overtime and an open miss late in regulation. Instead, they capitalized on the chaos presented to them.\n\n\"That's a great way (to describe it),\" Tatum said. \"That s -- was chaos. That s -- was wild, but just stay present, stay in the moment. As long as that time is still on the clock and the game is within reach, we feel like we have a chance. This core group has been in so many big-time games, big-time moments. We've had a lead and lost it and still won. We've been down a lot and figured out a way to win. I've had a lot of crazy endings in this building, so we've already been there before. And we always believe, in a sense.\"\n\nDid the win inspire more confidence that the Celtics will win the championship this season? To them, it didn't seem to matter. They stepped one win closer to their ultimate goal anyway. In the locker room, they have used the mantra \"whatever it takes.\" If they need to win a slugfest, they want to go ahead and do it. If they need to rescue themselves with a few key plays at the end of a bad outing, they want to figure out a way. If they can't pile up consistent stops and need to outscore one of the best offenses in basketball instead, they want to get it done. The Celtics allowed the Pacers to shoot 53.5 percent from the field, but yanked away the win anyway with an ending that packed more tension and excitement than the first two rounds of Boston's postseason run combined.\n\n\"I felt like we hit, they responded,\" Al Horford said. \"They hit, we responded. It was just a lot of back and forth. I think, despite all that, our group just stayed the course. We continued to work. We continued to try to play the right way. Eventually, we needed some sort of break and we got it there.\"\n\nThe Celtics nearly cost themselves many times. In the final 1:10 alone, Derrick White pulled up for a 3-pointer that Tyrese Haliburton swatted away; Tatum bricked a wide-open potential game-tying shot from the top of the key; and the Celtics botched a pair of close 2-pointers that would have pulled them within one point with less than 15 seconds left.\n\nThe second of those, a Tatum fadeaway from 16 feet, would have likely been shredded by the pundits if Boston had gone on to lose. With his team needing three points to tie, he followed a big offensive rebound with a dribble that took him from the restricted area toward the foul line. From there, Tatum didn't try to find one of his teammates for a 3-pointer to tie. He didn't try to produce a layup or draw a foul. His missed one-legged jumper over the top of Myles Turner could have doomed the Celtics. They prevailed anyway. Brown's pressure forced a turnover on the inbounds pass. Moments later, Brown tied the game with 5.7 seconds left on a fadeaway from in front of the Pacers bench.\n\nThe Celtics still needed a stop to force overtime. On the Pacers' final possession of regulation, Tatum switched onto Haliburton with force and physicality to prevent even a halfway decent look. Haliburton could only crash a desperation heave off the backboard as time expired.\n\n\"It was a hard-fought game and it was important for us,\" Horford said. \"We keep talking about protecting home court and it's whatever it takes.\"\n\nHorford almost seemed to chuckle as he mentioned protecting home court. He knew how close the Celtics came to dropping the series opener at TD Garden. They could have lost, and would have lost if the final 10 seconds of regulation -- the stretch from Indiana's misguided inbounds pass through Tatum's stop on Haliburton -- had been any less generous to them. If the ending had gone any differently, the Celtics would have had plenty of stretches to regret.\n\nAfter surging ahead 12-0 over the first three-plus minutes, they allowed the Pacers to pull within three points by the end of the first quarter. After producing double-digit leads in the second and third quarters, the Celtics again failed to hold onto the advantages. The Pacers bench, a key to the team's postseason success to date, brought an energy Boston couldn't match, at least when Tatum was resting. The Celtics failed to consistently slow down the high-powered Indiana offense, but saved themselves anyway with a shocking finish.\n\n\"You can't have any expectations about how it's supposed to go,\" Celtics coach Joe Mazzulla said. \"You miss a layup, you miss a 3, you give something up, it doesn't matter. I thought our guys had that kind of mindset.\"\n\nThe Celtics needed that mindset to prevail in easily their closest game of the postseason so far. Finally, after almost nothing but blowouts against shorthanded opponents over the first two rounds, the Celtics were welcomed into the playoff heat Tuesday night. They needed to fight through dumb errors. They needed to shrug off defensive lapses. They gave the crowd every emotion from raucous joy to stunned disappointment and back again. The ending to regulation barely made sense. In overtime, Tatum followed an and-1 layup with a sidestep 3-pointer to put the Celtics ahead for good.\n\n\"Nothing other than what I expected,\" Mazzulla said. \"Two high-level teams competing for a great opportunity. So I expect all the games to be like that, and there's going to be more of that. And I thought both teams competed at a high level. For us, I thought our guys -- obviously we weren't perfect, we can get better, but I thought we maintained a level of poise, a level of mental toughness to just continue to work through some of the mistakes. That's the bind they put you in, because of the way they play. So we handled it well, and we need to get better.\"\n\nBefore Tuesday, the Celtics had handled seven of their eight playoff wins by double digits. After the lone single-digit victory over the first two rounds, Jrue Holiday suggested he was happy in some ways to see his team in a closer game. Holiday's response revealed how methodically Boston handled the banged-up Miami Heat and Cleveland Cavaliers. For most of those two series, the Celtics were barely tested. They didn't need late-game heroics. They didn't have any gut-check experiences. They deserved credit for a boring start to the playoffs, which any team would want. But it was mostly boring.\n\nIt will take more later on. Even after the win, Brown sounded disappointed in the way his team played Tuesday night. The Celtics let Haliburton, T.J. McConnell and Obi Toppin run too freely. Even in Boston, the Pacers were comfortable and confident. Only 22 turnovers, including some very punishing ones, kept them from a huge offensive outing.\n\n\"I think it's always great to come out with a win,\" Brown said, \"but obviously we got to tighten up in some areas. We're going to watch the film. I think the majority of it was just transition. ... We knew they were going to be fast, it didn't surprise us, but it's one thing watching it on film and then seeing it in person. They just got out of a dogfight in New York and it just felt like they were just flying by us getting easy layups. We got to be better.\"", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "jay_king@nytimes.com", "name": "Jay King", "type": "author", {"uri": "8139559501", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "03:26:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T03:26:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T03:25:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://whdh.com/sports/tatum-scores-36-brown-hits-3-to-force-ot-and-celtics-edge-pacers-133-128-in-game-1-of-east-finals/", "title": "Tatum scores 36, Brown hits 3 to force OT and Celtics edge Pacers 133-128 in Game 1 of East finals - Boston News, Weather, Sports | WHDH 7News", "body": "BOSTON (AP) -- Jayson Tatum scored 36 points, including 10 in overtime after Jaylen Brown's tying 3-pointer with 6.1 seconds remaining in regulation, and the Boston Celtics rallied just in time for a 133-128 victory over the Indiana Pacers on Tuesday night in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference finals.\n\nJrue Holiday added a season-high 28 points and Brown finished with 26.\n\nGame 2 is Thursday night in Boston.\n\nTyrese Haliburton had 25 points and 10 assists for the Pacers, who knocked down 13 3-pointers and scored 56 points in the paint against a Celtics team still playing without 7-footer Kristaps Porzingis.\n\nPascal Siakam added 24 points and 12 rebounds. Myles Turner finished with 23 points and 10 rebounds for the sixth-seeded Pacers, who twice turned it over with a three-point lead in the final 30 seconds of regulation.\n\nBrown made them pay for the second one, hitting a 3 from the corner with Siakam right in his face to tie it at 117.\n\nIndiana went back ahead 123-121 when Haliburton hit all three free throws after being fouled with 1:46 remaining. Tatum then muscled in a layup and was fouled by T.J. McConnell. He completed the three-point play to put Boston ahead for good.\n\nThe Pacers turned it over again, this time by Haliburton. The ball found its way to Tatum at the top of key. He pumped, sidestepped a defender and sunk a 3 to make it 127-123 with 43 seconds left.\n\nDerrick White and Siakam traded layups. Holiday was fouled and hit two free throws to give Boston a 131-125 cushion.\n\n___\n\nAP NBA: https://apnews.com/hub/nba\n\n(Copyright (c) 2024 The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved. {"uri": "2024-05-364708474", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "14:11:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T14:11:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T14:05:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/celtics-news-boston-fans-game-1-early-before-jaylen-brown-shot-clowned", "title": "Celtics fans who left Game 1 early before Jaylen Brown shot get clowned", "body": "Boston fans are known as some of the fiercest and most dedicated in all of sports, but some of the Beantown faithful ended up looking pretty silly this time around.\n\nNow, to be fair, it wasn't that many C's fans, and the arena was still full for the overtime session. But still, leaving in a close playoff game like that is crazy. It would have been one thing if the Celtics were down double digits with two minutes left, but the Pacers were up by just five points with 1:57 remaining. Yes, they were also up three with the ball with 10 seconds left, but Andrew Nembhard turned the ball over with an errant inbounds pass.\n\nBrown then sunk the game-tying triple with six seconds left on the clock, and the Celtics got a stop to force overtime.\n\nDid the Celtics absorb the Pacers' best shot in Game 1?\n\nThis was nearly a disastrous loss for the Celtics, even with how shaky they have been at home in the playoffs the last few years. Dropping Game 1 of the conference finals in your own building to a largely inferior opponent? Where have we seen that before?\n\nAnyway, Boston was able to get the job done by making clutch plays on both ends, which is something the C's have been widely criticized for not consistently doing throughout the season. Perhaps the Celtics needed a close game like this to build some mettle.\n\nThis may also end up being one of the closest games Boston may play in this series.\n\nThe Pacers shot a blistering 53.5 percent from the floor and were absolutely making some unbelievable shots. Many of the three-pointers that Tyrese Haliburton and Co. sunk were very contested, but they just happened to fall.\n\nIndiana is a very good three-point shooting team, ranking eighth in percentage and ninth in makes this year. But some of the shots the Pacers were draining in Game 1 will probably not be falling very much for the remainder of the series (if it continues, the Celtics may be in some trouble).\n\nYou kind of get the feeling that this may have been the best offensive performance Indy will put forth in this set, at least on the road. The Pacers just scored 128 points (117 in regulation) in Boston. Against one of the best defensive teams in the league.\n\nMaybe the Pacers will be able to have another hot shooting night at Gainbridge Fieldhouse, but it seems kind of hard to imagine Indiana doing this again in Beantown.\n\nIndiana also got over 20 points from each of Haliburton, Pascal Siakam and Myles Turner and still lost. When your three best players perform that well and you still lose, it's tough. On the flip side, though, one can argue that the Celtics got 90 combined points from Jayson Tatum, Jrue Holiday and Brown, and the Pacers managed to hang in there.\n\nWe'll see if Boston can take a commanding 2-0 lead on Thursday night, something the C's were unable to do in their previous two playoff series this spring.", "source": {"uri": "clutchpoints.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8139823775", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "07:09:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T07:09:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T07:08:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.nba.com/news/celtics-pacers-5-takeaways-from-bostons-ot-triumph", "title": "5 takeaways: Celtics turn Pacers miscues into OT win", "body": "BOSTON - Someone tried to throw Tyrese Haliburton a lifeline during his rather glum postgame session with reporters Tuesday night.\n\nIt was a tough outcome for his Indiana Pacers, a 133-128 overtime loss to the Celtics in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference Finals. So one of the inquisitors charitably tried to frame it and spin it all at once: Does it help to know they didn't win the game as much as you guys lost the game?\n\nThe Celtics weren't just happy beneficiaries. The Pacers didn't have control of all that took place. You could tell it stung by how often the Pacers' point guard sighed and shook his head. But he found a through line for his team as this moves forward.\n\n\"What I will say is encouraging,\" Haliburton said, \"is that we've been trash in Game 1s, first series and second series. And today we played great for about 47 minutes.\"\n\nThe Pacers got spanked in Game 1 in Milwaukee a month ago, then took the series in six. They lost Game 1 at New York (and Game 2 for that matter) in the just completed seven-game conference semis, yet here they are.\n\nThe trouble Tuesday was, this one lasted 53 minutes. Forty-seven wasn't near good enough. Game 2 is Thursday (8 p.m. ET, ESPN).\n\nHere are five takeaways from the victory at TD Garden that put Boston up 1-0:\n\n1. That's the way to open a series\n\nIt was big, it was sloppy, it was crammed with key plays and glaring mistakes - and it was just what NBA fans should have wanted as the table-setter for as many as six games to follow.\n\nThree times, the Celtics built, then blew double-digit leads. Twenty-two times, Indiana possessions ended in turnovers. Boston only trailed for 2:41 in the game's first 43 minutes, yet needed every Pacers gaffe and Hail Mary moment it could muster just to force overtime.\n\n\"That [expletive] was chaos,\" Boston's Jayson Tatum said.\n\nIndiana coach Rick Carlisle threw himself under the bus because he didn't use a timeout with 10 seconds left, his team up 117-114 and Andrew Nembhard searching, searching for a teammate with his inbounds pass. The ball went out of bounds off Pascal Siakam and, naturally, the Celtics capitalized when Jaylen Brown took Jrue Holiday's inbounds pass in the left corner and drilled a line-drive, game-tying 3-pointer.\n\nHad Carlisle used the timeout, the Pacers would have inbounded at the far end. Less stress, less panic. Fouling Brown? No good, because the Celtics wing already was squared up to the basket.\n\nThen Haliburton had the ball as regulation ran out, dribbling himself into a thicket of defenders.\n\n\"I understand [Carlisle is] protecting us, protecting me as well,\" Haliburton said. \"But I'll take that more than he should. I've got to be better and I will be better in Game 2.\"\n\n2. The shoes, oops, gotta be the shoes\n\nHaliburton seemed incredulous over his turnovers. He only had three but two in particular were game-changers. And they were unforced, in his opinion.\n\n\"There were three different occasions where I dribbled the ball off my foot,\" he said. \"I don't know what happened. Nobody forced it. Frustrating, to say the least.\"\n\nThe two most damaging came on the left sideline, and he lost the ball out of bounds both times. The first was with 27.7 seconds left, snuffing hopes of extending that 117-114 lead. In the final minute of OT, he did it again and what was a 124-123 Celtics lead stretched to 127-123 when Tatum hit from way out top.\n\nLet it be known, Indiana was a top-10 team this season in not turning over the ball, and of the four teams left, it entered this round with the lowest turnover rate (11.6 per 100 possessions). The 22 miscues matched their second-most all season.\n\nBoston does have a pair of All-Defensive guards in Jrue Holiday and Derrick White. But Indiana's whoopsies came every which way. Jitters seemed part of it early.\n\nIt was so debilitating that no one from Indiana bothered to grumble about Boston's 30-10 advantage at the foul line.\n\n3. Night lasted long enough for Tatum\n\nTatum missed five of his seven shots in the fourth quarter, including a 3-pointer out of a timeout with 36.7 seconds left and his team down three. If not for what was described above, he would have been hearing more and louder criticism about his inconsistency and unreliability.\n\nThen in the five minutes of overtime, the Celtics' smooth forward scored 10 of their 16 points. Five of them came off free throws. He had a 3-point play in which he abused Pacers guard T.J. McConnell inside. Then that dagger that let Boston manage its four-point lead near the end.\n\n\"He just plays with a level of poise and a level of comfort,\" coach Joe Mazzulla said. \"Knowing that the next one has a chance to go.\"\n\nTatum finished with the gaudiest numbers of the night: 36 points, 12 rebounds, four assists, three steals, 10-for-12 from the line and a game-high plus-20. But he shot 12-for-26 from the field, including 2-for-8 on 3s, so there still is room for nitpicking.\n\n\"Prove? It doesn't prove anything,\" Tatum said of the performance. \"We won a big-time game. Series is far from over.\"\n\nAt this rate, Tatum will be hearing and responding to his critics right through the NBA Finals.\n\n4. This is a 'No Dame Lillard' zone, so...\n\nNo need to rub any noses in the fact that Boston's Jrue Holiday still is playing and that guy for whom he was traded is not. We can say that the veteran point guard was the Celtics' most vital player Tuesday, scoring 28 points (many to bail out sketchy possessions) and captaining the defense. He had seven boards and eight assists.\n\nMazzulla said: \"He's the kind of guy that can impact the game in different ways every night.\"\n\nHaliburton called Holiday \"the best defender in the NBA, and he has been for a long time.\"\n\nHoliday just said his mission, and his message to teammates, in Game 1 was to keep coming. This was only the second official \"clutch\" game of the postseason for Boston in 11 outings and the team has shown a tendency to play down to the level of its foes.\n\n\"Continually being aggressive,\" Holiday said of his readiness. \"Continually working on my game. Continually having the coaches and my teammates in my ear telling me they're going to need me.\"\n\nKeeping pace with Indiana's preferred up-and-down style was key - the teams combined for 128 points by halftime. Things got noticeably grittier from there.\n\n5. Biggest coaches' challenge gap ever?\n\nUntil we hear otherwise, we're going to proclaim that Boston set an NBA mark for the greatest amount of time between using its two challenges. Mazzulla turned on the green light just 35 seconds into the game to overturn a goaltending call against Al Horford. That kept Indiana from tying the game ... at 2-2.\n\nRewarded with a second one, Mazzulla used it with just 12.9 seconds left in overtime. He hoped to overturn a foul on Tatum, but lost that one. Obi Toppin sank two free throws for the Pacers' final points, briefly making it 131-128.", "source": {"uri": "nba.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBA.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-364337435", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "09:01:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T09:01:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T08:57:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.cnn.com/2024/05/22/sport/indiana-pacers-boston-celtics-eastern-conference-finals-spt-intl/index.html", "title": "Indiana Pacers head coach takes responsibility for Game 1 loss to Boston Celtics in Eastern Conference Finals", "body": "Indiana Pacers head coach Rick Carlisle said he should have called a timeout in the final seconds of regulation time.\n\nCNN --\n\nIndiana Pacers head coach Rick Carlisle said the 133-128 overtime loss to the Boston Celtics in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference Finals on Tuesday was \"totally on me\" after his team snatched defeat from the jaws of victory.\n\nThe Pacers had a three-point cushion and the ball with just 10 seconds left of regulation time, but Andrew Nembhard's inbound pass to Pascal Siakam ended up in Indiana turning the ball over.\n\nThe costly mistake was punished by Jaylen Brown who leveled the scores at 117-117 with a three-pointer from the corner. The Celtics then got the better of overtime to take a series lead, leaving Carlisle to rue the missed opportunity.\n\n\"I love the way our guys fought in this game. This loss is totally on me. With 10 seconds of regulation, we should have just taken the timeout, advanced the ball and found a way to get it in,\" Carlisle admitted to reporters after the game at Boston's TD Garden.\n\n\"We made some other mistakes, but our guys just need to concentrate on fighting the way they fought in this game, from start to finish.\"\n\nDespite Carlisle taking responsibility for the chaotic end to regulation time, it was an error strewn night from the Pacers, who tallied 22 turnovers which led to 32 points for Boston, according to ESPN.\n\nCarlisle, though, wanted to focus on the positives of which there were some. Boston, for example, had twice led by double digits in the game but Indiana came back on both occasions to take the lead.\n\nBoston Celtics guard Jaylen Brown forced the game into overtime with a three-pointer in the final seconds of regulation. Charles Krupa/AP\n\nThe Pacers head coach was confident his team would recover in time for Game 2 on Thursday.\n\n\"We did a lot of good things that we need to continue to do and we've been a tough minded, resilient team for almost the entire second half of the year and we have to continue that,\" he added.\n\nFor the Celtics, it was a morale boosting start to the series, with Brown and Jayson Tatum leading the charge.\n\nTatum finished on a game-high 36 points, coming up clutch in overtime after Brown had saved the day.\n\n\"Welcome to the NBA Playoffs,\" Brown told reporters. \"You've just got to manage your emotions of the game. Anything can happen. The game is not over until the final buzzer sounds.\"\n\nThe Celtics were also boosted by a career-best performance from Jrue Holiday who totalled 28 points, seven rebounds, eight assists, and three steals.\n\n\"We've seen crazy stuff happen all the time,\" Holiday told reporters.\n\n\"I don't think that we think we've lost a game until we've actually lost a game. That's part of the reason why we were so resilient toward the end of the game; anything can happen.\"", "source": {"uri": "cnn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CNN"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8139588918", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "03:58:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T03:58:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T03:57:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/celtics-pacers-game-1-lebron-james-foul-reaction-comments/", "title": "LeBron James Critical of Key Decision Late in Pacers-Celtics Game 1", "body": "Game 1 between the Pacers and Celtics featured a dramatic end to regulation.\n\nHighlights Pacers missed chance to foul with a 3-point lead, leading to game-tying shot by Celtics' Brown. LeBron James emphasizes importance of fouling up 3 late in the game to prevent a 3-pointer in a critical social media post. Pacers coach takes blame for not executing fouling strategy, calls loss to Celtics in Game 1 'totally on me.\"\n\nGame 1 of the Eastern Conference finals saw the Boston Celtics snatch victory from the jaws of defeat against the Indiana Pacers.\n\nWith just 10 seconds left in regulation, the Pacers led 117-114, and with possession, looked to be in complete control of the game. But after a turnover on the inbounds pass, the Celtics suddenly had a bit of life.\n\nAt that moment, the Pacers had the opportunity to foul the Celtics as soon as they got the ball in play, sending a Boston player to the line for two free throws, rather than giving them a shot at tying the game with a three-pointer.\n\nIt didn't happen, and after getting the ball in the corner, star swing-man Jaylen Brown hesitated to fool his defender, and drilled the game-tying shot.\n\nIndiana couldn't score on their final possession, and the Celtics went on to win in overtime by a final score of 133-128.\n\nAs soon as Brown hit his shot, Los Angeles Lakers superstar LeBron James weighed in on the play, emphasizing that it was always best to foul when up three points in a late-game situation.\n\nJames knows a thing or two about late-game strategy, and the finish between the Pacers and Celtics underlined what he sees as an easy decision when leading by three late.\n\nPacers Coach Rick Carlisle Said Later That the Plan Was to Foul A heads-up play by the Celtics prevented the Pacers from playing the possession the way they had planned.\n\nAfter the game, Pacers head coach Rick Carlisle took the blame for the loss, adding that the plan was to foul, but they just didn't get the chance to execute.\n\n\"[Brown] caught the ball. He was face-up, so Pascal just decided to lay off, which was ... I understand that's probably the right decision. You don't want to give up a four-point play. A lot of things had to go wrong for us and right for them. They did.\"\n\nIt was a brutal loss for the underdog Pacers to take early in the series. Heading into the conference finals, the Celtics were heavily favored to move on to the NBA Finals representing the East, but had Indiana stolen Game 1 and flipped home-court advantage, their chances of reaching the title round would have jumped by several measures.\n\nInstead, the Pacers will have to regroup after losing a game they would have won 99 times out of 100, and try to do it all over again in order to avoid falling in a 2-0 hole in the series.\n\nGame 2 tips off in Boston on Thursday night.\n\nRelated Chris Paul Linked to Los Angeles Lakers, per Report Chris Paul could be looking for a new home this offseason. Then Jayson Tatum made a crucial late three-pointer to push the Celtics to victory and a 1-0 lead in the best-of-seven series.\n\nTatum top scored for Boston with 36 points, 10 of them in overtime, collecting 12 rebounds and four assists with Brown putting up 26 and Jrue Holiday 28.\n\nIndiana, who fought back from large deficits several times in the game, were led by Tyrese Haliburton's 25 points, 10 assists and three rebounds with Pascal Siakam making 24 points, seven assists and 12 rebounds.\n\n\"Welcome to the NBA playoffs. You've just got to manage your emotions. Anything can happen,\" Brown said of his tying three-pointer. \"It's not over until the final buzzer sounds... It's not over until it's over. We found a way to win the game at the very end.\"\n\nStill, Brown was far from happy with the performance from Boston, who had almost a week off after their 4-1 series win over the Cleveland Cavaliers.\n\n\"A lot of ups and downs, I don't think we played our best,\" the three-time All-Star said.\n\n\"We almost dropped the game on our own floor. So we have got to come out and be better,\" he added.\n\nGuarding against complacency was also on the mind of Tatum. The Celtics have lost Game 2 in each of their previous two series.\n\n\"It doesn't prove anything,\" Tatum said. \"We won a big-time game. The series is far from over.\"\n\nThe Pacers came into the game on the back of a grueling Game 7 win against the New York Knicks on Sunday and Boston were the fastest out of the traps.\n\nWith the put Boston 87-77 up, but again Indiana came back and with less than two minutes to go they led 115-100.\n\nIndiana turned the ball over twice in the final 30 seconds of regulation before Brown's {"uri": "8140468083", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "13:43:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T13:43:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T13:42:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/us/nba/news/pacers-choke-game-1-celtics-2024-eastern-conference-finals/1fb3e6b69cdca832fefd81d8", "title": "Pacers choke Game 1 vs. Celtics: Turnovers, non-foul plague Indiana in 2024 Eastern Conference Finals", "body": "The Pacers dropped Game 1 of their Eastern Conference Finals with the Celtics in one of the most painful ways possible.\n\nAfter trailing Boston by as many as 13 points in the third quarter, Indiana regained the lead with under five minutes remaining in the fourth. Things then went awry in the final moments of regulation.\n\nWith 10 seconds left in the fourth quarter, the Pacers had the ball, a three-point lead and a win probability of over 90 percent. A few mishaps later, Indiana was gearing up for overtime against the East's No. 1 seed.\n\nHere's what went wrong for the Pacers in the fourth quarter and overtime.\n\nMORE: How Celtics survived thrilling OT clash with Pacers\n\nTurnovers plagued the Pacers throughout Game 1. Indiana committed 21 turnovers in the game but none were more crucial than the two it committed in the game's final 30 seconds.\n\nWith a 117-114 lead, Indiana got a crucial stop and regained possession with an opportunity to make it a two-possession game. Tyrese Haliburton committed an unforced turnover, dribbling off his knee to give the Celtics the ball back.\n\nDespite the mishap, the Pacers got another defensive stop, forcing the Celtics to foul with 10.0 seconds remaining. Because Indiana was not yet in the bonus, it had to take the ball out from the sideline, setting up its most crucial turnover.\n\nAfter the Celtics regained possession, things went from bad to worse for the Pacers.\n\nWith 8.5 seconds remaining, Boston, trailing by three, inbounded the ball from under its basket. Jaylen Brown briefly freed himself to the left corner before being met by an intense closeout from Indiana's Pascal Siakam.\n\nBrown remained poised and hit an incredibly difficult corner 3 over Siakam, who did his best to not foul.\n\nBrown's game-tying 3 immediately brought back the philosophical discussion of whether or not basketball teams with a three-point lead should intentionally foul to prevent teams from tying the game.\n\nLeBron James was among the many to chime in.\n\nMORE: LeBron James chimes in on Pacers' decision not to foul at end of regulation in Game 1\n\nDespite the demoralizing end to regulation, the Pacers still had opportunities in overtime.\n\nWith 1:46 remaining in the extra period, Haliburton sank three free throws to put Indiana back up by two points. It would be the Pacers' last lead of the game.\n\nOn the ensuing possession, Indiana allowed three offensive rebounds before Jayson Tatum put Boston ahead with an and-one finish. One play later, another turnover from Haliburton caused a change in possession. And the Celtics took a four-point lead after a Tatum 3 with 42 seconds remaining.\n\nThe Pacers would turn the ball over again on the next possession and Boston's lead grew to six points after a Derrick White layup. Indiana would play the foul game from then on but it was too late.\n\n\"With 10 seconds (left) in regulation, we should have just taken the timeout, advanced the ball and found a way to get it in, and made a free throw or two and ended the game but it didn't happen.\"\n\nCarlisle called back to Nembhard's turnover after Boston's first intentional foul with 10 seconds remaining. The Pacers had one timeout remaining and, had they used it, would have advanced the ball to the front court.\n\nInbounding the ball in the frontcourt would have greatly decreased the chances of such a catastrophic turn of events for Indiana.\n\n\"We made some other mistakes,\" Carlisle added, \"but our guys just need to concentrate on fighting the way they fought this game from start to finish and we'll be back Thursday.\"\n\nIndiana dropped a golden opportunity to steal home court in Game 1, but it will be right back in action less than 48 hours after the final buzzer sounded.", "source": Then Jayson Tatum made a crucial late three-pointer to push the Celtics to victory and a 1-0 lead in the best-of-seven series.\n\nTatum top-scored for Boston with 36 points, 10 in overtime, with 12 rebounds and four assists. Brown added 26 points and Jrue Holiday 28.\n\nIndiana, who fought large deficits several times in the game, were led by Tyrese Haliburton's 25 points, 10 assists and three rebounds with Pascal Siakam adding 24 points, seven assists and 12 rebounds.\n\nBrown was far from happy with Boston's performance after they had almost a week off following their 4-1 series win over Cleveland.\n\n\"A lot of ups and downs. I don't think we played our best,\" he said.\n\nThe Pacers led 115-100 with less than two minutes left to play in regulation but turned the ball over twice in the final 30 seconds.\n\nPacers coach Rick Carlisle said he was to blame for the shaky finish.", "source": {"uri": "thestandard.com.hk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Standard"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.1372549019607843, "wgt": 178, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8140083839", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "09:50:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T09:50:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T09:50:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.masslive.com/celtics/2024/05/who-says-the-celtics-cant-pull-out-a-close-playoff-game-guregian.html", "title": "Karen Guregian: Who says the Celtics can't pull out a close playoff game?", "body": "BOSTON - If the Celtics go on to claim Banner 18, their Game 1 overtime win over the Indiana Pacers in the Eastern Conference finals might prove the most pivotal during the championship run.\n\nThe knock on the Green Team during the season, as well as past playoff appearances, was their lack of finish, their inability to win the close games.\n\nThey needed to get over that hurdle to assuage the fears of their doubters, and perhaps fears of their own.\n\nAnd while Tuesday night's 133-128 overtime win was both infuriating and exhilarating, the Celtics ultimately showed their mettle and resolve when it counted.\n\nYes, they wilted, blowing a 13-point lead with four minutes to play in the third quarter. They sure seemed to be headed down a familiar path. But just when it looked like they were destined to keep the choke collar, they rose up. They grew strong in those pivotal, got-to-have it moments.\n\nThey took advantage of the countless gaffes made by the Pacers, making them pay for their miscues, but none greater than the one with a few ticks remaining in regulation.\n\nDown three with the clock running down from 10 seconds after the Pacers umpteenth turnover, Celtics forward Jaylen Brown calmly hit a corner bomb to tie the game and send it to overtime.\n\nBrown, who had a disasterous Game 7 performance in the Eastern finals last season, said he basically willed the shot in ahead of time.\n\n\"I was just telling myself the whole time, if you get it, it's going up and it's going in,\" Brown said. \"I was able to make a big-time play.\"\n\nHe sure did with Pascal Siakam in his face as he launched his off-balance prayer to tie the game.\n\nThen it was Jayson Tatum's turn to be the hero. He scored 10 of his 36 points in overtime, including a three-pointer that put the nail in the Pacers coffin with 42.8 seconds to go.\n\nTatum, who was having a rough shooting night (12-of-26, 2-of-8 from three), finally dialed it up during crunch time.\n\nBut the dynamic duo weren't alone.\n\nJrue Holiday, who has largely sacrificed his scoring this season, also rose down the stretch and overtime with 20 of his 28 points coming after halftime.\n\nBottom line: The Celtics needed to win a game like this. If they do advance to the NBA Finals, they needed to know they can deliver in key spots, in the big games.\n\nAlthough, listening to the players after the game, they never doubted they were capable.\n\n\"I think we always knew we could (win),\" said Holiday. \"Close games I don't think have ever bothered us. I think we've always stayed poised no matter if it's a win or a loss. We'd always give ourselves a chance again today. But, down 3, with some seconds left, making a big shot, and making big plays after that, we knew we had it in us.\"\n\nOf course, the Pacers were a willing accomplice. They helped the Celtics, giving them life, or, as Tatum put it, \"a second chance\" with all of their bumbling. Their whopping 21 turnovers led to 32 Celtics points.\n\nAt different points during the fourth quarter when they seemed to have the game in hand, the Pacers just gave the Celtics more chances time and again. Ditto overtime.\n\nTalk about not knowing how to close out a game, the Pacers took the cake in Game 1.\n\nAndrew Nembhard's wayward inbound pass with 10 seconds to play set up Brown for the tying score. Then how do the Pacers not foul Brown, who is not the best free throw shooter in the world, before allowing him to take that three?\n\nIt's almost an automatic to foul if a team is up by three with little time left on the clock.\n\nEven Pacers had coach Rick Carlisle fell on the sword for his team's meltdown, saying he should have called a timeout to advance the ball, and draw up a better in-bounds play.\n\nSo maybe the Celtics were lucky. Maybe the Pacers gift-wrapped the win. By the same token, they took advantage of their good fortune.\n\n\"I felt like we hit, they responded. They hit, we responded. It was just a lot of back-and-forth,\" Al Horford said following the Game 1 win. \"I think, despite all that, our group just stayed the course. We continued to work. We continued to try to play the right way. Eventually, we needed some sort of break and we got it there. I'm glad we were able to close it out in overtime.\"\n\nAdded Holiday: \"I think we always knew there was a chance. We've seen crazy stuff happen all the time ... Anything can happen. We're just the type of team that's going to keep fighting, no matter how long, no matter what it takes.\"\n\nThe Celtics were able to snatch a victory out of defeat. In many cases, it's been the other way around. They've grabbed defeat, out of sure wins.\n\n\"It's not over til it's over,\" Brown said, spouting a familiar refrain, \"and we found a way to win this game at the very end.\"\n\nFinding a way in Game 1, could very well pay bigger dividends when they're forced to muster up similar resolve down the road.", "source": {"uri": "masslive.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "MassLive"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indiana_Pacers", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Indiana Pacers"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston_Celtics", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Boston Celtics"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Overtime_(sports)", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Overtime (sports)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaylen_Brown", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Jaylen Brown"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jrue_Holiday", "type": "person", "score": 3, "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Pascal Siakam"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Nembhard", "type": "person", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Andrew Nembhard"}}, {"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-364082732", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "04:36:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T04:36:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T04:34:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://eu.indystar.com/story/sports/columnists/gregg-doyel/2024/05/22/pacers-shouldve-won-at-boston-in-game-1-of-eastern-conference-finals/73776486007/", "title": "Doyel: Pacers could've won - should've won - Game 1 in Boston. Bodes well for future, right?", "body": "The Pacers shot an NBA playoff record 67.1% from the floor to beat the Knicks 130-109 and advance to the Eastern Conference finals.\n\nBoston Celtics guard Jaylen Brown is in the corner, and he's not going to make this shot. The 2024 Indiana Pacers, the most underappreciated Eastern Conference Finals team since, ahem, the 2013 Indiana Pacers, are about to storm out of another garden with another NBA playoff win, this one at TD Garden in Game 1, two days after beating the Knicks in Game 7 of the Eastern Conference semifinals at Madison Square Garden. All the Pacers need is for Brown, hemmed in the corner between Paskal Siakam on the court and Bennedict Mathurin on the bench, to miss this prayer and this game's going to --\n\nInsider Dustin Dopirak: Pacers don't foul, Jaylen Brown's 3 forces OT, and Celtics win\n\nMore: LeBron James, others believe Pacers should have fouled while up three points\n\nThe Pacers, who let this one slip through their fingers in the final seconds of regulation, threw the damn thing out of bounds in overtime. This was a game they could've won despite committing seven more turnovers, should've won despite attempting 20 less free throws, but didn't win because their best players made some bad mistakes at the worst time.\n\nBoston stole Game 1 with a 133-128 victory in overtime, and if you'd like to feel better about this for a moment, re-read the first four words of this sentence:\n\nBoston stole Game 1.\n\nYou can tell me the Celtics are the No. 1 seed in the Eastern Conference, went 64-18 in the regular season - seven more wins than anyone else in the NBA - and barely broke a sweat in winning each of their first two series by a 4-1 tally. You can tell me the Pacers are the No. 6 seed, won 47 games in the regular season and needed six games to beat a Milwaukee team missing MVP Giannis Antetokounmpo, then seven games to beat a New York team missing half its roster.\n\nYou can tell me all that, and it's true. But so is this:\n\nThe Pacers could've won this game Tuesday night in Boston. No, they should've won this game Tuesday night in Boston.\n\nMakes you think the Pacers are going to win a handful of games in this series, eventually. Who knows? Might even win four.\n\nBoston stinks. Well, it does.\n\nEnough with the positive spin, though hang around. More coming, but first we've got to address what went wrong, because this was a playoff game, this was a loss, and after playing with valor for most of the first 47 minutes, the Pacers didn't exactly acquit themselves well in the final minute of regulation, or most of overtime.\n\nIn Boston, where the rude people are actually the nicest folks in town, memes of a dog urinating down its leg - hey look, it's the Pacers in Game 1 - were circulating on social media. Because that's what they do in that miserable town. They mock a No. 6 seed for almost beating the No. 1 seed at home.\n\nYou can have Boston.\n\nBut can the Pacers please have a better handle on the basketball Thursday night in Game 2? The Pacers committed 21 turnovers Tuesday night, and sure, some of that was caused by a Boston defense that is the stingiest, peskiest in these playoffs. The Celtics have a handful of elite defenders among a roster of savvy, smart veterans, and those guys made things difficult on the Pacers. Know who else made it difficult on the Pacers?\n\nThe Pacers made it difficult on the Pacers.\n\nIt started early, when the Celtics roared to a 12-0 lead after the Pacers missed three layups and committed two turnovers in the first 2\u00bd minutes. It was later in the quarter when Tyrese Haliburton drove into the lane and kicked out a pass to T.J. McConnell, who could've caught it only if he'd been sitting in the crowd.\n\nIt was Obi Toppin committing a series of absurd turnovers in the third quarter, as I noted in the play-by-play I keep. On one turnover, it says in my barely legible shorthand, Toppin dropped a pass out of bounds. On the other, it says only: \"Toppin: silly turnover.\"\n\nLook, if the Pacers can give away an Eastern Conference Finals game on the road, against the No. 1 seed, because of 21 turnovers, you damn right I can quote my own notebook. Might as well quote Pacers coach Rick Carlisle, too, especially since he sat down for his postgame remarks and immediately said:\n\n\"This loss is totally on me.\"\n\nCarlisle explained why, and while he's wrong about that, we'll double back to it in a moment.\n\nPacers lose, but it's a special group\n\nThe Pacers do have something special here, and the country saw what we already know.\n\nHaliburton was playing with joy, making a 35-footer in the final seconds of the first half and sinking a double-pump 3-pointer at the third quarter horn, then skipping away in glee. Haliburton had 25 points and 10 assists, including a pair of no-look passes to Siakam for dunks.\n\nSiakam was playing with force, going for 24 points, 12 rebounds and seven assists. Aaron Nesmith and Andrew Nembhard were playing their way into their next contracts someday - 14 points and six rebounds for Nesmith, 12 points and seven assists for Nembhard, hard-nosed defense by each against Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown. And Myles Turner was lighting social media on fire in the first half, scoring 18 of his 23 points, including a run of 10 straight that started with one of his angry, reach-way-back dunks and ended with a pump fake followed by a slide step to the left for a 3-pointer.\n\nTurner scored those 10 consecutive points, so obviously he was hot, but he passed up an open 15-footer moments later when he spotted Nembhard alone in the corner. Nembhard made the 3.\n\nThis is a team that plays hard, plays the right way, and plays with class - not a single jerk, nary a Donte DiVincenzo or Patrick Beverley to be found on this roster. America saw that Tuesday night, and will see it five or six more times this series. Might even see it in the NBA Finals. Who knows?\n\nDoyel before Game 1: Pacers are still here, and whatever happens vs. Boston, aren't going away\n\nBut America also saw this team lose its composure in the final minute of regulation and overtime. Leading 117-114 in the final 27 seconds of regulation, the Pacers turned it over twice; Haliburton dribbled it out of bounds with 27.1 seconds left, and Nembhard threw an inbounds pass out of bounds off Siakam with 8.1 seconds left.\n\nThat's where Carlisle was trying to take the blame, continuing his first quote above like this:\n\n\"We should have just taken the timeout, advanced the ball and found a way to get it in and make a free throw or two and win the game,\" he said. \"It didn't happen and we made some other mistakes, but our guys just need to concentrate on fighting the way they fought in this game from start to finish, and we'll be back Thursday.\"\n\nEven with those late turnovers in regulation, Boston couldn't capitalize - missing four straight shots in the final 70 seconds - but Brown didn't miss No. 5. That was his 3-point heave between Siakam and Mathurin to force overtime.\n\nThe Pacers had their fingers on this game again in overtime, but like the ball kept doing, the game slipped away. After hitting a 3-pointer for a 120-117 lead and then making three free throws to make it 123-121, Haliburton lost another ball out of bounds. Then Siakam had the ball taken from him by Brown. Then the Celtics, who kept scoring at the other end, had a 129-123 lead with 20 seconds left, and it was over.\n\nThat's the bad news, and while there is finality to Game 1, the rest of this series is there for the taking. Sounds crazy, I know. Boston won 64 games! It's the No. 1 seed! Actually, it sounds like you're shouting. Settle down, and keep this in mind: Boston shot a respectable 47.5% from the floor, made 15 shots from behind the arc, committed seven less turnovers and attempted 20 more free throws than the Pacers.\n\nAnd still Boston needed the Pacers' help to win this one. At home.\n\n\"A lot of things had to go wrong for us and right for them,\" Carlisle said. \"They did, and so we've got to own it - and we've got to get ready for Thursday.\"\n\nFind IndyStar columnist Gregg Doyel on Twitter at @GreggDoyelStar or at www.facebook.com/greggdoyelstar.", "source": {"uri": "indystar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Indystar"}, "authors": [{"uri":
